column10: I don't know what they changed but civilization 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 +6 I probably played 5000-7000 hours plus the other 4X games I played here and there and in 2024 the game is no longer the way I remembered it. I was used to play my civilization 4 and 5 and 6 at prince and/or king difficulties but now, in the 4, I just played whole day today and I made 5 or 6 games and I failed them all. I was about to retry at warlord difficulty but I decided to just uninstall instead! The game is fully unbalanced. I was always using the "balance" resource but the bots very often started right in middle of 234723427 luxuries, Ghengin Khan came attacking me with wtf 47 units + 2 vassals, in another game I tried stacking 75 units in 2 groups and I had time to capture only 2 cities before the bot and its ally come counter-attack my face like butter. ffffuuuuccccckkkkk that ! The techs, you are ok for half the game, you trade 1:1 with the bots and you follow them, then BOOM they get 5-10 tech ahead of you under just 15-30 min of playtime wtf, this game is completely broken ! What I remembered about this game is me playing with Louis XIV and capturing the bots cities but now I can only capture a single city in a whole playtrough. They for sure changed something ! (I was using a cultural leader + making cultural buildings + 20-30% gold per turn in cultural and the bot next to me, in my last game, was beating me super easily, probably with this wonder, a christian one I think, a church or something if I have good memory but this wonder, a couple years ago, was making the bot equal to me. Now, with a single wonder, you beat the shit out of your neighbors. UNINSTALLED ! I go go retry Civilization 3 and cry more !

When this expansion came out, I actually considered it as inferior to Warlords. However, i have learned to appreciate it since then, though it did require time, particularly as I had to learn how to use the new concepts and mechanics. Now, still playing the game pretty often, I consider such innovations as corporations and espionage as exactly those elements, that the previous instalments lacked. I do believe that I'll still be playing this in the future.

Just one more turn!!!

Simply the best civ, I started almost 20 years ago and I'm still playing to this day. Sometimes I don't play a couple of months, then I start a new game, maybe 2, repeat. I keep coming back to this gem of a game, it calms me down because it makes me think. 'One more turn' is this game for me, just like it's commercial back in the day. I play mostly turn based games because I have a slow reaction time ( ADD, getting older and kids ) like age of wonders, hearts of iron, xcom, etc. But civ4 will always be my favourite, it just never bores me. My praise is long but I'll try and keep it short and why this beats the bad later civ games.

The good:

-Every turn matters, I almost never click next turn without doing or thinking something. For instance in civ5 in the short period I tried it, I had nothing to do. Build a thing in the city, 30 turns, move your unit, that's it.... nothing. In civ4 I'm thinking about keeping my scout alive, scouting next city spots, thinking on what tiles to micro to get the most out of my cities, what specialists to run, what tech to go for, etc. There is always alot going on that keeps me invested. 
-The quality of the game and it's fanbase: this game always runs, even on a crappy pc. Heck the full game on disc came without DRM, you could install it on a friends pc without issues. Because they trusted the fans to actually buy it to support it. It came with a manual 200 pages thick which I've read countless times when I was younger. And the most friendly people on the planet will answer all your questions on civ fanatic, with tons of great mods. Heck I just started playing again to try realism invictus, another huge mod that changes everything. All free! 
-The UI is amazing, sure it looks clunky at first but with some basic mods everybody uses and that are easy to install ( Bug, bat, etc ) you see EVERYTHING that you want to see. No hidden info, no menu's in menu's ( yes I'm talking about you horrible civ5 ), hotkeys for most things, waypoints, etc. Once you master this game you will WANT all this information and it's there, to let you focus on the fun part. Actually playing the game! 
-Some people hate the look of the graphics, for me it's one of the positives. I love the colourfull world, the tiny buildings and wonders you can actually see in the cities themselves. Heck my 3 year old daughter looked at my worldmap yesterday, just enjoying the animal animations, the scenery. You can tweak the graphics a bit with more mods like marble, but personally it's fine. Yes I've been playing for a long time but the graphics are part of it, because they follow the need of the game not the other way around. I can instantly see what is what, for instance the difference between a hill and a mountain. A jungle or a forest, what the resources are, what the units are ment to be, etc. This sounds simple enough, but do you ever find yourself losing time in newer games thinking what the hell is that?
-Turns are fast, this game runs milky smooth. I found myself frustrated at games like civ5 or homm4 where even early game you click next turn and the game just lags for 10 seconds for some reason. 

Could be better: 

-Me and a friend of mine used to play alot of mp and the game was prone to some desynch issues sometimes. Still not sure what kept causing it, but we usually worked it out after reinstalling. 
-After all these years some balance issues were never adressed, but there are thousands of mods for this. 
-You will lose track of time, but hey the game has an ingame clock that you can even use as an alarm ;)
-You will hate all other civlike games after mastering this. Yes I'm looking at you hexbased games with 1 unit per tile. 
-You will forget to make a review even after 20 years, because you've been to busy playing the game. ( untill now )
-You need to finish your games to learn young padawan, restarting constantly only gets you so far ;)

Steam doesn't count the hours I have in this game before it got on steam, I'd be well over a 1000 by now. Buy it, the BTS expansion is essential. Look on civ fanatics to learn the game, they are the most friendly people on the planet. Easy to play, hard to master. Have fun! :D

Why am I writing a review on an.....  old game?  It is excellent in it's simplicity.  There are years worth of mods and resources to customize your gaming experience to fit your needs.  You aren't going to tax your system with graphics so it can focus on processing the turns of the game at a quick speed, especially when compared to newer versions of Civilization in which turns on a massive map may take a 30 seconds.   I'm a fan of marathon speed games as they allow you to explore and require a little further planning.  When it takes 15 turns to build a combat unit, you make damn sure you're prepared.

I played this for hundreds of hours in tyhe days before steam, using a CD. It is one of the iterations before we arrived at CIV VI. I have played everyone from the first one. At the end of the day, I must admit CIV VI is the best one with the DLC's. Besides gameplay, the world is so much better aesetically. In VI, one can see all one's wonders in the area around the city. In IV, they are hidden within the city. However, they don't take up any valuable real estate like they do in VI. 

City management is much better in VI. In IV, the aeas are marked in squares. In VI, they are round making the borders more natural. Resources are much less in IV. Military units are stacked in IV rather than spread out one to a hex as in VI. I like the districts in VI, which IV doesn't have. There are other minor differences. I recommend IV, but only as a nostalia trip. 75/100

I vividly remember my older brother bringing home Civ IV not long after it came out, excited to play it, only for our crappy family computer being too weak to play it. A few months later we got a new one, and I was able to start playing it in the early morning or whenever he was gone. I've taken breaks from it for years at a time, but I always find myself coming back.

The game has aged graphically, but if you're willing to look past the stacks of doom and unit spam that can bog the game down towards the end, you'll find a game that is still fun and full of depth without ever feeling overwhelming. If I was able to learn how to play it (poorly) when I was 9, you can too. The mechanics provide depth in a way that allows a skilled player to leverage them to their advantage, without punishing someone who doesn't. Additionally, this makes the AI significantly more competent than in VI since it won't fall so far behind because it can't plan districts 200 turns in advance. Civ IV's modding scene also adds a significant amount of content, although I have never really dabbled in them myself.

I'd consider Civ IV one of my top 10 favourite games of all time, across all genres, and I highly recommend it to anyone that is a fan of the genre.

After all these years, Civ IV stands out as the best one for me - and yes I've played them all. 

In my opinion, IV offers the best balance between fun, gameplay challenge and customization. Squares are just better than hexagons, and quite possibly the only gripe with it is stacks of doom, however... it's a feature not a problem. 

All that being said, get into the modding scene for which IV has the most content available of all iterations of Civ. Just to name a few popular ones: Fall from Heaven, Rise of Manking, Realism Invictus and my all time favourite, Caveman 2 Cosmos are there to add hundreds more hours of fun to a game that could already stand on its legs.

Edit:

The best version of civ in general. Civ 4 in general expands on Civilization 3's features and content with the expansions expanding on vanilla. This is without factoring in mods, of course.

Sid Meier‚Äôs Civilization IV is an addicting 4X strategy game. As a leader of one of the eighteen civilizations of the base game (that can become even more with the two expansions, Warlords and Beyond the Sword) the player is expected to explore the surrounding lands (in a potentially procedurally generated map) and expand their city borders, found new cities or conquer others to gradually become an empire and eventually win a campaign that spans from the stone age to the near future of 2050. Victory can be achieved in many ways, from being the first civilization to reach outer space, to remaining the only civilization that is left on the map. The most interesting and addicting factor of Civilization IV are the choices the player takes, each one leading their civilization‚Äôs progress in a different direction. The technology tree is interesting and varied, allowing to focus on military prowess in one game or scientific progress in another; each choice could be the better one, depending on the map, the adversaries and the success in building world wonders or founding religions. Accompanying these potentially endless games are decent graphics that are clear to understand despite the complexity of the system and an incredibly (and award winning!) soundtrack. The Warlord expansion adds six more civilizations, more leaders and unique scenarios to the main game, but is otherwise unremarkable. The Beyond the Sword expansions is a lot better, adding ten more civilizations, more leaders, more unique scenarios and late game buildings; it also adds natural disasters and expanded victory conditions, making the end game a lot more interesting. Civilization IV ‚Äì The Complete Edition is an amazing package, with virtually endless fours of fun that players want to spend time with, even if just for‚Ä¶ one‚Ä¶ more‚Ä¶ turn‚Ä¶

One word,
[i]Rhye's and Fall of Civilization[/i]

alright, that was several words,
but that's beside the point, the point is mods like Rhye's made this game great.

And looking back now, it was probably the best time for mods,  at least in the universe of Civ, mods at the time could actually change the fundamentals of the game, and the game was transformed into very different ones with different mods, and it was fantastic!

Mods like [i]Rhye's and Fall of Civilization[/i] was so unique, that years later, I still find myself wanting to go back to it, and I have to fight the urge every god damn time, 

"the graphics are just so aged." I'd tell myself. 
"but the game-play is gooooood." myself would counter.

Arguments continues......
...

"So what?! Download it again then, you wouldn't last more than 5 minutes anyway." I'd always bring this final argument every-time every few years.

"Challenge accepted."

I'll post an update with a proper review, once I'm finished with the game once again. this time.

Maybe I'm looking through my rose-tinted glasses, maybe it's nostalgia speaking,
but given the fact that I still think about it enough to want to actually play it after this long,
I think I will have to recommend it, until I don't. ;p

0/10 Stars. Game sucks.

-1 Star for stupid cartoonish leader pics

-1 Star because it does not make it easy to identify (by simply looking at the map) which of your cities have Hydro Plant, Coal Plant, or Nuclear Reactor.

-1 Stars because having a Hydro Plant + Coal Plant + Nuclear Reactor in the same city nets you NO benefit BUT does still have all the penalties of the individual buildings (ir reactor meltdowns and health loss)

-1 Stars because the game ALLOWS you to accidentally build multiple Power sources in the same city, even though there exists no benefit (and only penalties) for doing so.

-6 Stars because it does not allow you to demolish buildings.

Obviously, poor design. If a city only benefits from having a single Power source, then it should not allow you to build multiple Power sources UNLESS it will also allow you to demolish redundant/useless/harmful buildings.

Somehow Firaxis designed a game superior to Civilization 1 while also being less than Civilization 2, imho.

EDIT: Played some more, same complaints but need to add the Culture Flipping nonsense to the list.

So -2 Stars for Culture resulting in non-military border changes.

And -3 Stars for making it possible for a city to be lost due to Culture alone.

Going back to Civ2.

For veterans of the Sid Meier's Civilization series, Civ IV built on a lot of the features which had hooked us on earlier versions of the game and improved upon them.  The remixes of the original player faction themes from Civ 1, with the addition of tons of additional period-appropriate tracks, made the music very enjoyable to listen to, even as a soundtrack album away from the game.  The Beyond the Sword expansion lacked the gorgeous intro movie and the Christopher Tin "Baba Yetu" main menu song of the Civ IV base game, but it built upon Civ IV: Warlords' introduction of the Warlord special unit by adding (I think) other types of special single-person units who could help your civilization in other ways (such as the Great Prophet, Great Scientist, etc.), and by introducing special events (which your civ could respond to in various ways) and Quests (meet the quest's goal before a certain deadline, and gain a benefit for your civ).  Your civ could also found a religion if you were the first to discover certain technologies, and could use missionaries to "win friends and influence people (other civs)".  Finally, Civ IV was much more moddable than had been Civ III, and some of the mods (which could require either just the base game or either of the expansions) are still some of my favorites today.  (Hope that "Planetfall" mod will still work with this!)  Highly recommended!

I started playing the Civilization series at V and I've also played a bit of VI. Both are pretty great in different ways. So I bought the IV bundle to see why it's so hyped my many fans of the franchise but it's all nostalgia. 

First, the DLC aren't expansions that add to the base game but stand alone copies that you have to install separately. I found this out after purchasing the bundle and this one is apparently the most complete version so here I am as opposed to leaving a review on the base game's page.

Second, let's talk mechanics. Combat is terrible since I couldn't find a way to attack from a distance with ranged units. Trebuchets and archers attack just like melee meaning there's no way to protect them from counter attack which is really dumb. The ability for land units to embark on sea tiles is so far down the research tree that it's also really dumb. If a nation you're at war with lands on your city and there's not a military unit on the tile, it just takes your city. 

I could go on but I'm not wasting any more time on this review or this game pointing out how it's just Civilization V with far worse mechanics. I'm glad I started at V and haven't gone farther back because V seems to be the pinnacle of this style and VI plays way different than previous titles. If you aren't nostalgic for this game, save your money and play V or VI instead.

Having played Civ V and VI first, Civ IV is a pretty big adjustment but it's one I think is worth making. It plays so dramatically differently from the newer games and not just in a "old game super simple" kind of way like Civ III and previous, I regularly play it alongside its sequels and get something out of each.

The flow of the game is more variable than the newer games which kind of box you into specific strategies based on the civ you pick. In Civ IV the leaders have different traits which make them fairly unique, but in general they don't lend themselves so heavily towards specific victory conditions. It's more intuitive to have your approach to the game be based on the map, the diplomatic situation, available resources, etc. There are lots of different strategies for different scenarios and it makes it possible to play the same leader or similar leaders twice and have very different games because you dont have to commit to some linear strategy from the get go, which I feel is the game's greatest strength. I also like that diplomacy is more feasible and interesting because you can actually cultivate meaningful relations with the AI, compared to V and VI where the AI literally realizes its in a game and behaves irrationally. There are a few other cool mechanics and details like being able to turn rivals into vassal states instead of conquering them outright which can be convenient and creates a cool dynamic, and overall the game feels satisfying as both an intricate strategy game and a good representation of real world society and history which is a focus I think Civ VI especially kind of lost.

The particularly weak area in my opinion is the combat. You usually end up stacking countless units on the same tile and moving the stack around which eliminates much of the intelligent use of space and terrain of the newer games. The units are also largely based around a kind of checks and balances system where you have a big stack made up of various kinds of units designed specifically to counter one another, it comes off as a pretty goofy and meta gamey thing at times. Overall I think conquest is a lot less satisfying than in the newer games, but it isnt awful either. 

I definitely recommend checking the game out, maybe look up some playthroughs first if coming from Civ V or VI as the game is pretty complex and very different.

Still a great game, even when compared to CIV6. Playing against the AI in CIV4 is more interesting than it is in the newer CIV6. The final and best iteration of the first CIV games (I - IV), that allowed multiple units per tile. It is a more complex version of CIV III, adding religion, and unit promotions.

There are two ways to build up your economy, hamlets (that are build around the cities and turn into towns), and specialists (that live in cities). There are advantages and disadvantages to both, giving the game some complexity.

The tactics during combat are complex enough to make it interesting but not overly complex. The most controversial part of combat is collateral damage, which allows units such as cannons to damage multiple units per tile. Collateral damage takes effect during attack, making it important to attack first. However, who gets to attack first depends more on luck than tactics. Units move slower in enemy territory, because they can not use roads (, unless they have a specific promotion), which limits the maneuvers that attackers can do in enemy territory. The slower movement is a bit of a flaw of the game.

The best version of Civ there is, and once you've sunk enough time into the historical game to raise a kid or two, try out the Fall From Heaven 2 mod for a game where every kingdom plays by its own rules and religion means something, it's insane fun.  (you will need the PDF guide).

The general consensus on the [i]Civ4[/i] expansions is that [i]Warlords[/i] was largely unnecessary, while [i]Beyond the Sword[/i] is a real expansion that makes the original game bigger and better. And the general consensus is completely correct. [i]BTS[/i] overhauls the espionage and space race systems and adds a fairly complex corporation mechanic, on top of new diplomatic options, creative random events, and even an unexpected ‚Äúquest‚Äù mechanic. It makes me wonder why [i]Warlords[/i]‚Äô barely-present features weren‚Äôt just postponed for inclusion in this pack. It‚Äôs still not the kind of expansion that makes you think it could‚Äôve been a whole sequel, but even if its new features aren‚Äôt enticing, it adds several palpable quality of life improvements (and some expected mechanical tweaks) that make it the definitive version of an already classic game.

The best Civilization game. Obviously I have played more than nine hours. I played CIV V and CIV VI and just could not take it anymore with how annoying the games are. I believe what happened is the franchise went downhill when Take Two bought it back in 2005. The creator of Old World, Soren Johnson, developed CIV IV and co-designed Civ III which was good in its own part. I have been playing the franchise my entire life, since I was eight years old playing Civilization II. Such a great franchise through Civ IV. I personally did not hate CIV V with the added DLC and Mods created, but it is not in the same league as CIV IV. Well, it would be very hard for me not to recommend any of Sic Meier's work to anyone, especially a player who enjoys strategy games. I have never been a fan of online multiplayer games because of the immature psychological attitudes and biases that these players inadvertently bring to their games. NOW, I am 74 years old and learned about computers and the internet when I was in my late 40's as an English professor. so that is definitely a source of my attitudes about multiplayer gaming. 

So, going beyond these kinda complex issues that are really more a personal thing, with me, I would say that most people are not so much stuck on making sure I feel realism while playing strategy games and this is what gives me permission to recommend the game to a much wider span of people than I might normally allow myself. I hope this makes sense to everybody.

An absolute gem of a game and a staple of the Real Time Strategy genre, one that helped me to understand just how amazing and brilliantly made these types of games really are. CIV4 BTS was a game that my dad and I bonded over for years, as he taught me everything he knew about how to play, and we made the most of all it has to offer. Every game is a new experience, no two will progress in any way close to the same as one another. The sheer variety of nations, leaders and units alone is enough for hundreds of hours of experimentation, all absolutely worth the time it takes to learn. This game is timeless and near-flawless, a cornerstone of its genre and a must-play for anyone interested in turn-based strategy games.

Civilization 4 and above have beautiful graphics. Civilization 4 and below use classic rules (later games switch to a hexagonal grid and remove military unit stacking). This is the "sweet spot" of the series.

I only find one thing objectionable: "obsolescence". This is a mechanism that among other things eliminates the effects of some buildings and/or wonders when a particular technology is discovered. The worst example of this is the Scientific Method, which paradoxically reduces your scientific output by obsoleting monasteries and the Great Library. Obsolescence can be removed by editing an XML file, however. IIRC .\Beyond the Sword\Assets\XML\

It bothered me that State Property was mechanically better than Free Market, but the addition of corporations in Beyond The Sword fixed the problem.

I've spent over a week of my life watching my civilizations collapse because I picked the wrong civics in Rhye's and destabilized them.

The US Department of State trains one of the most robust foreign language programs in the world. Ambassadors representing the US have to go through extensive classes to reach fluency. Native English speakers spend around 600-750 classroom hours for proficiency in Spanish and French, German about 900 classroom hours, Hebrew and Greek around 1100 classroom hours, and the hardest level, Arabic and Mandarin Chinese about 2200 classroom hours. 

This week I hit 1000 hours playing Sid Meier's Civilization IV (Civ4). And what a fun 1000 hours it was to experience. That is some serious time investment, as I could have had an ambassador's fluency of most European languages with that time. And those are hours just on Steam, not including the unrecorded CD Rom hours I played in the old days before Steam. A lot of these hours were racked up during the pandemic of 2020, and time spent playing went in tandem with hanging out w/ friends in an activity more interesting than a phone/video call. 

The game teaches you a lot about strategy, culture, history, resource management, and even language (the game is operated in English, French, German, Italian, and Spanish). One of the gems with the game is the well thought out, information dense, Civilopedia. It is an ingame information guide that is user friendly to perfection. In-game content describing the most basic warrior unit, to the history of Bismarck's Germany, is easily contained and categorized, accessible with multiple embedded hyperlinks during the game. If anyone is reading this who needs to open a website, buy the game and tinker w/ the Civilopedia. It's how most information packets should be operated. Easy to look up info, clickable photos with information makes a great product years after launch. 

Another category with this game that's fantastic is that you learn how to manage resources better. Patience will be the best tool at your disposal as you learn how to employ effective supply chain links to your armies, planting the seeds of commerce with cottages, and conserving Great People for future gameplay exploits. So many in-game wars with friends were fought to the last military unit, in a struggle for survival in an ever increasing difficulty level as we got better through experience.

 I‚Äôm very fortunate to have enjoyed Civ IV with good friends and gotten the opportunity to share the game with new players who caught on quickly and enjoy the game too. If I could make a request to Steam on tweaking the game, would be to allow more than 4 human players on a game. There‚Äôs 18 max slots for AI players but for human players the limit is 4 human players. Involving more of our friend group would be immense fun. Also if you could save a Worldbuilder map for multiplayer use would be awesome too, but don't know how much Steam can do on that front. Thanks Civ IV, there‚Äôs a lot one can do with 1000 hours; spending it with friends building empires through tough times and good times, long after the 2007 game release date, has been 1000 hours well spent.

Maybe Im Ollllddddd School - Civ 4 is my fave by far. Ive tried civ 5 -6. I WANTED SO MUCH to like them, I really really did. Those hexes tho..so beautiful and strategy packed. Long story short - I bought this on sale for price of a big mac, and loaded the mod CAVEMAN2COSMOS into it.
This mod makes 5-6 look like an 80's arcade game. There are probably more units available in the prehistoric age, than there are in either one of the other civs mentioned all totaled. There are undoubtabley more buildings in the mod than both games combined. The research tree makes both games look like they only thought to give you the instructions on a 2$ cake box mix. The unit promotion tree makes 5-6 look like they were made for the mobile platform. Spend 3 days on wiki browsing through them all - you wont...
There are more options & settings in the Caveman2Cosmos menu - than the top 10 AAA games combined. The options run on for days....
If you lust after a long epic strategy game - Grab Civ4 off of steam, and DL the 1gb Caveman2Cosmos Mod.
 *Im not responsible for any marriage breakups*

EDIT > So I am 30hrs past my last review - still in the prehistoric age - and the caveman to cosmos mod is even BETTER than I could ever imagine. This mod has no competition. NONE. It IS in a class of its own. It is safe to say ; I havent even crossed into the ancient era, and I have had a better journey thus far than every civ game combined put together. And thats saying alot; I bought the very first Civ game almost 25 years ago.  The Caveman2Cosmos mod will rule your night and day. I think about it when Im sleeping. I think about it at work. I think about it when Im on my 4 wheeler hanging off the edge of a possible cliff. There is not another strategy game game that can even come close to this. The developers of caveman2cosmos put INCREDIBLE thought into this mod - and after 100hrs of playing it surely shows. Cant wait to get into the Ancient Era. Im on turn 2398. It shouldnt be long.                                                                                                                                  
Review Update*  786hrs later. Same game roll as initial review. Try to keep it short. The reason I havent got back sooner is just.... one....more .  ..  turn. 
Keep in mind were hard mode, gigantic map, slowest research (epic)
Civ 4 is the King of all Civs > but coupled with Caveman2Cosmos, it is utterly fantastically phenomenally mind blowing. Im on turn 4798 now, I just hit classical era. (prehistoric>ancient>classical) and there are I think 9 eras left. Ingenious game, Ill give no spoilers, but it gets better every turn. If your a civ fan, or call yourself a wargame strategist, and have not played this mod ; you are truly missing out. Cheers to Sid Meier's. Cheers to the total geeks who made Cave2Cosmos. Next turn.

Civilization IV: Beyond the Sword is the second expansion to one of the best turn-based strategy games of all time. As this is an expansion, and not the base game, I'm not going to detail all of my thoughts about the game here. Feel free to look up my Civilization IV game review for that.

Pros and Cons specifically for this expansion:

Pros:
+ Some minor mechanic improvements.
+ "Corporations" as a sort of "religion" feature is a fun addition.
+ The Space Victory and Diplomatic Victory features were expanded nicely.
+ The Espionage feature is introduced earlier in the game, making is useful.
+ The Final Frontier mod is one of my favorite Civ IV mods.

Cons:
- Sometimes the new "random events" can frustrate the heck out of you. There were a couple of times when I was hit with several negative random events in quick succession, messing up the war campaign I was on.
- The infamous "Stacks of Doom" of the oldest Civilization games is still present here. (And IIRC, for the last time.)

Rating: B+ (for its time), B- (for 2021)

Like the base game, the Beyond the Sword expansion can often be found on sale. If you already own the base game, you may find it worth it. I enjoy it.

It's a war game with rules that make wars almost impossible to win by not letting cities produce for many turns after they are captured, and even worse, it often just plain gives a conquered city back to the enemy along with your military units that you left in there to defend it.

You can turn off giving the cities back in the settings, but it will keep asking you, "the citizens are *rightfully* asking" to be given back to another empire, as if the freaking game has some sort of moral authority. It's incredibly annoying.

The entire espionage subgame is annoying and unpleasant to play. You can turn it off, but then you are left with wonders and buildings that serve no purpose, just taking up space in the menus.

The suggestions are often annoying. It often gets into a state where it's asking you every two or three turns if you want to make a settler unit, even though there is no place to put a settler, and there is no way to say, "Stop asking me this." And if it thinks its time for you to build a wonder, a dozen cities will have that suggestion in the popup, even if you start building it in the first one. This means that you have to scroll down in the menu to find the next thing each of those dozen cities needs to build. And if you don't want to bother with that wonder, even worse; then it will be taking up that valuable slot for a dozen cities for many turns.

Finally, the game is also politically snotty. It raises the 20th century mass butchers Stalin and Mao to the status of great leaders, even though neither actually did much for their country. But not Hitler, who actually did rule over Germany while it went from a disastrous economy to one of the greatest war machines in history. I'm not saying they should have included Hitler; the fact that he was a mass butcher is good enough reason to ignore him, but Stalin and Mao were just as bad. The difference is that white university-educated pseudo-intellectuals think Stalin and Mao were mass-murdering heroes.

Then there is making the Mt. Rushmore wonder available with the discovery of fascism--a deliberate slap in the face to American patriots. Another slap at America was replacing the Hoover Dam with the Three Gorges Dam. The Three Gorges Dam was just another big dam. It wasn't an engineering first like the Hoover Dam was.

As you probably know, CiV IV is different to civ V onward in allowing multiple units to operate in the same area, so it is more like the game "Risk".  This can make it quite hard if you play at Noble level or above - unless you make a strong start you will find yourself gradually falling behind.  I would say it favours aggressive play in the early stages to ensure you have room to expand and all the resources you need, then very focused play in the later stages to make sure you hit one of the victory conditions first (so if you are best placed for a cultural or space victory, you concentrate on that and not on conquest). Well worth playing.

The one, the only, the very best of CIV games - CIV 4 BTS is for me the pinnacle of the series. This is coming from someone who has played them all 1-6 (though 5 and 6 significantly less). 

The graphics may not hold up anymore, but the mechanics, the tech trees,  the resource rush, the many ways to develop and steer your civ are yet to be surpassed IMHO.

If you havent tried it, i recommend you do, though keep in mind if coming from later CIV titles that the difficulty is a bit more steep and the resources are far far less present, so the AI will try to get them before you do.

I've been playing this game since I bought it at a Target store in Illinois in 2006, so don't let the 19 hours of Steam game time fool you. I was playing the heck out of the Games For Windows version until I decided to go digital. Since then I would play it off and on in between newer versions of Civ, but I always go back to this one because of the faster pace of the game and, of course, the late Leonard Nimoy's narrations. 

The graphics are horribly outdated now, but the gameplay is still what this game is all about and thankfully the game still holds up, even better than Civ 5 and Civ 6 in a lot of ways. I still enjoy stacking my units before sending them off to raid civilization capitals, which remains to this day the best strategy to beat another civilization in a war, in any version of the game. Religions have more meaning in Civ 4 than they do in later iterations of the game; Civ 5 has the silly piety thing, while Civ 6 has religions it keeps them on the back burner and the whole "create your own pantheon" thing in that game never grabbed me all that much as a concept; there was always a rebellious feeling whenever I opted to turn the American Empire into a communist Islamic state just for poops and giggles! 

Whether you buy it on sale or not, Civ 4 Beyond The Sword is still the ideal game to get through your Civ sessions in a hurry. Even with the Marathon and Huge maps running, you're still feeling like you are rushing through the game even when you are in it for the long haul. No other Civ game moves at the pace that this game does, and you will love every minute of it.

Civ 4 is in my opinion the best of the franchise because it gets the balance right, and also has high performance. What I mean by performance is that there is little-to-no lag between turns. Arguably the best 4X ever made.  The the BUG mod, which is built in with this edition (I believe) or which can easily be installed so as to provide a superior interface, makes this an 11 on a scale of 1-10.  Incredibly deep and incredibly addictive;  experts as well as aveage players come back to this from time to time.  I think it is a good prediction that it will be the best game on your hard drive EVER.  No, that's wrong.  The best game on your hard drives that you will have as you upgrade from time to time..   (It does play perfectly on Win10, btw. 
 That's a  pretty galactically crazy thing to say, but I am confident.   It's 20+ years old (although with the full set of expansions counted, since it doesn't really hit GOAT without them, I think its a little less than that.  No matter.   Civ 3, 5, and 6 are all very good games, but this is the shining start.
Why?   You have to play it, for quite a while, to really understand.  Ignore that 60+ hrs It says I have played.  Bull, I surely have put hundreds if not thousands or  hours in, and it is fresh and inviting every time.  Note there are TONS of excellent guides on steam and on the internet, I particularly like Sulla's guide.  It's got deep strategy pouring out all  over itself, from diplomacy to religion to corporations.  Oh there are tons of scenarios you can  play also...I haven't tried them much because the base game is such a treat.  Multiplayer is possible and playable but I don't recommend that unless you can get people together for hours at a  time,.  One has to think, one has to plan, one has to hope.  You can play 20 hours while constantly feeling like the roof might fall in any second,  
If  you really don't know about this game (really?) you might want to watch a Civ 4 let's play by Quill18.   If you don't like 4X, then why are you reading this?  Otherwise, if you haven't already you have the Holy Grail of turn based strategy.  Stop reading this and get busy gaming.

Beyond The Sword is by far my favorite strategy of game of all time and will most likely stay that way. Over the hundreds of hours I've played of Civ 4 (about 550 including original Civ 4) I've never been bored leading a country to greatness, or waging war and making great allies. The AI immerse you into the experience of dealing with political disputes and having to try make do with World leaders from ancient to the industrial age. As Montezuma ruthlessly demands things and is very hard to please if you don't listen to his trade requests or ignore him, to playing humble Gandhi who's spiritual and more open to speaking friendly. Or maybe be the first to build the great wall of china, or the Apostolic Palace and the United Nations. I absolutely love Civ 4 and always will. This game has given me and others lots of memories as I still continue to usually play it day to day. Give it a shot you won't regret it.

Best of it's kind, hands down.  I've never stopped playing it.  I've had lulls, certainly, but there's no game I've played more consistently (my experience dates back to Pong).  It's the gold standard.  Civ 4 set the bar under which all others shall pass, including its own sequels.  The graphics are of course dated, but it's really as good as it needs to be.  This is a timeless classic, with endless complexity, an engaging & flexible AI, never-ending replay-ability, just-one-more-turn appeal, phenomenal balance, and a true monument to the gaming world... and then there's the mods!  As with anything, it's not for everyone, but for those of the persuasion, it has no equal.  Buy the game, with Warlords and Beyond the Sword, and start working on your excuses for why you slept through your alarm; it will happen.

Absolute classic.  I have it on a different platform as well, so my hours played is probably 5x higher than what Steam shows. I'm not the biggest fan of the espionage addition in the expansions, but again, it's able to be turned off.  Game is addictive, be prepared to lose a whole weekend.  And another.  And another.  I highly recommend getting the expansions.  I also recommend the Epic speed setting, it's the best balance between resources and time - anything shorter and by the time you've built a unit it's about to become obsolete.  Especially if they have to travel any kind of distance, they'll be obsolete before they arrive.

Also beware of Isabella of Spain, she's out for blood.

I have bought and played Civ V and Civ VI, they aren't as fun.  The map in IV is cleaner, it's easier to see what's happening, city influence areas are more regular etc, for my OCD brain this level of tidiness is important.

The advances from the previous iterations are also welcome - getting rid of the caravans, and unit costs being tied to the city of origin...  The added Wonders, religions, politics/leader personalities and trade/diplomacy is great, a valid and fun addition.  Also more balanced than past games. I'll start by saying that this is not a game for casuals, if you want to have a game that is incredibly compelling and complex and rewarding to learn, this is your game.  While Civ 3 remains a complete mystery to me, I can say I have played all the others, and this one is by far the best I've played.  You might say "what about Civ 5?", but I highly prefer it to Civ 5 for several reasons (unit stacking ***Figure out how to use collateral damage people***, tech/espionage/culture slider, much more micromanagable empire, better system for unit and city maintenance, far superior espionage system, more interesting promotion dynamics with military units, unrestricted leaders, non gimmicky leader traits, non gimmicky religions, far superior map options, way less annoying barbarians, way less buggy multiplayer, etc etc etc...)

I have dumped hundreds of hours into this game on steam (untold hundreds more on my non steam copy) multiplayer on the steam servers just last year and still have no fatigue of this game.  The replay value is incredible and you can even find interesting strategies with unrestricted leaders.  If you like Civ 5, and have never played Civ 4 BtS, and want to take your Civ experience to the next level, I highly recommend this game for you.  It can be overwhelming at first, I know, but give it time, it's a seriously good game.

I'd argue that this is the best Civilization yet made. It still has huge faults - things like how diplomacy will at its best serve a minor role in your play style and more than likely be essentially be forgotten, you're no longer able to use bombers to destroy roadways which really weakens their use, a sea-based invasion on an opponent is near impossible until fairly late in the game and even then you need to have a sizable military that you're completely devoting to capturing an insignificant foothold, I feel like Great Generals are nowhere near as useful as their peers (except of course Great Spies which are completely forgettable), etc. - but the game still has enormous potential. The addition of religions and corporations adds a fun and unique strategic element to the game that its predecessor was missing and the expansive wonder list not only continually tempts players but also provides play variety in terms of focus. (Though it becomes obvious pretty quickly which wonders are considerably overpowered when compared to others - I find myself always striving for Stonehenge if it looks like it's in range, the Eiffel Tower is also considerably useful if you anticipate being a war monger that needs captured cities to expand quickly, and I almost always settle an early game city near a river solely so I have a shot at constructing Three Gorges down the road.) I know many had complaints regarding unit stacking and that's largely why Civ games following IV no longer allow it, but I feel like stacking is not only vital (to a degree) when it comes to playing this game but that it actually adds a fun additional element to the game where you then begin to consider things like "supply lines" as you wage a war deeper and further into enemy territory (obviously both war parties are stacking their units, so is it worth the risk to try and spread your units thinner to try and sweep cities away from them quicker or will you leave yourself too exposed?)

Overall, I'd highly recommend this game. Main things I wish they'd fix is allowing roads to be destroyed via air units again and having diplomacy take a more commanding role.

Civilization 4 is one of the better iterations of Civilization, and this review is of the complete game, rather than just this expansion. I started playing Civilization with the original DOS version, I played Civnet too. I bought Civilization 2 back in the Windows 95 era and kept it on my hard drive for over a decade. So I have some experience with what I am talking about here. Perhaps the only thing that would make this version of Civilization better would be the addition of Civilization 5 style religions, as religion in this version is fairly poorly implemented. I played this for literally thousands of hours before I got it on Steam, and, as of this writing, have 714 hours here. This is despite me owning both Civilization 5 and 6. For me it's a toss up as to which game represents the apex of the series, Civilization 3 or 4, but Civ 4 wins based solely on the tech issues of playing older games mean that I can still easily play it on a newer PC.

I played this game for like... three years straight, at University. It's pretty good, I guess.

What makes me go back to this after trying the alternatives:
- This is a city management game first, a battle strategy game second. A consequence of this is the square tiling, instead of the hexagonal one used in battle games.
- Stacks of Doom are easier to handle instead of carpets of doom
- Making too many new cities is controlled by adding bigger taxes to those specific new cities instead of punishing the whole empire. This means that if those cities will eventually be good profitable additions to your civilization, then it's worth the investment.
- Diplomacy is perfect. Trading works as intended and you can always understand why another leader hates you or loves you.
- Pretty graphics. Colorful, unrealistic. The game is pretty and kinda silly. You'll get feedback for every interaction against other leaders.
- Late-game turns are still fast and if you make queues or automate city productions and workers orders then it will require minimal output from you.
- Civilopedia has links from one article to another.

I've been around the block to know this is a contentious opinion so I will not say this is the best Civ game there is; it's only my favorite.

Graphics stand up to modern standards even today; the modding community takes it to a whole different level and transform it into different 4x games with barely anything in common.

The interface is gorgeous and you can always easily find the information you need to make the decisions to take your empire to the place you wanted it to be. Going wide and going tall are both feasible and your starting position and resources heavily influence what your strategy is going to be without being forced to one particular playstyle only depending on your starting Civ.

There are a few things to polish; and to be fair I am still in love with the hexagon maps instead of squares; but again, the map community has you covered. I can't find any gripe on this game at all.

It's also hard. Really freaking hard! If you up the difficulty enough; you'll face a challenge.

Civ 4, by itself, is a worthy entry in the Civilization franchise, and at least a couple hundred of the hours I have logged on the game are Base Game plus expansions. They were fun, but the next couple entries in the series topped it, as Firaxis keeps doing new and cool things with this amazing franchise. The reason I have nearly 4000 hours logged on this game is the mod Fall From Heaven 2 (with probably 500ish hours being me literally asleep in front of my keyboard after a marathon, or leaving the game on while I go do something else). Even subtracting a generous 800ish hours from my total, this means I have something along the lines of 3000 hours played on a single version of a single game. 
Fall From Heaven 2 is worth every hour spent. It is an insanely rich reimagining of the base game. A full-conversion fantasy mod that adds memorable characters and storylines to a genre that you would think would handle those poorly, but the leaders, factions, and scenarios allow you to participate in dozens of engrossing stories of the history of Erebus.
FFH2, from what I've read in forums and articles, started as a Dungeons and Dragons campaign played for quite some time by several of the original creators of the mod. They used the characters and storylines from their DnD campaign to flesh out their omage to Master of Magic, an absolutely stellar full conversion fantasy version of Civilization 1, done by Microprose many years ago. They brilliantly intertwined concepts from MoM and their DnD campaign to create something mostly new, with enough concepts from their inspirations to tug at the nostalgic heart strings of many an old nerd.
There is entirely too much content to cover it all, but it is all brilliantly put together, fairly well balanced, and offers excellent choices for heroes and villains of all kinds of tactical flavors.

TLDR: You can pick this game up cheap, the Fall From Heaven 2 mod is free. Get them both and prepare to lose significant stretches of the rest of your life to this amazing game.

Played Civilization IV for over 10 years with 1000+ hours before getting the Steam version. It's November 2020 and I still think it's the best Civilization game ever. It's the most well balanced with the best diplomatic options and tons of great mods still being made. Absolutely addictive.

I have played "Civilization III", "IV", "II", "V"  and "VI" (in that particular order). "Civilization V" is my favourite, but "Civ IV" has also a lot to offer and it's worth playing not only for nostalgic value. Everything what I'm saying relates to "Beyond the Sword" expansion and I highly recommend to purchase all the expansions, because, without them, the game is incomplete and you have limited mod and civilization options. (Actually, I don't understand, why people play vanilla versions. For "Civilization" games, it's usually like this: they release an incomplete game with some gameplay faults, which is substantially improved with following expansions ‚Äì not only in terms of content, but also in terms of mechanics.)

Here are some things that "Civ4" does have that "Civ5" doesn't, and things that "Civ4" is better at (well, imo, at least):

+ More customisation options (e.g., no limitations regarding how many civilizations could there be per map size; an option to assign leaders to different civilization, for example, Ghandi as a leader of Russia).
+ By far better interface (except, for one thing - when you are offered research/tech choice, you need to make decision right away - you can't examine your empire first. You can change it afterwards in the same turn, but, anyway, it's not very convenient). Apart from that, it's more easy to review the overall state of your progress. For example, howering over a tech gives you a detailed explanation of what you can achieve with a tech (units, wonders, bonuses for discovering first, etc.), why it's important and where it leads. Also, in "Civ4", there is the option to see the network of global politics or what a particular leader thinks of other leaders or what he wants or is willing to trade. I also prefer "Civ4" icons over "Civ5" icons.
+ Unit appearance is different for each civilization and religion (and not just in terms of colour). For example, Korean swordmen will have different swords than European swordmen, a Buddhist missionary will have a different outfit from that of a Christian missionary.
+ Cool wonder animations.
+ Civics (ideologies) are available much earlier in the game, you can change them more easily and they are not linked to culture points. In "Civ5", many of the civic system functions are transfered to the relligion system.
+ Map trading
+ Cultural victory is actually a feasible option contrary to "Civ5", where it is possible only in rare occasions.
+ Inbuilt World Builder (In "Civ5" it's available only from the "Workshop")
+ Workers can build forest preserves (that add happiness)
+ The rather unique "Afterworld" scenario and "Final Frontier" mod (which both feel like and actually are completely different games ‚Äì full-conversion mods, if you like).
+ Vassal states (you can push other leaders to become your vassals).
+ No lag on large maps, since it is a much older game and requires less system resources.

+/- Random events instead of city state quests
+/- Workshops and windmills are tile improvements instead of buildings. 
+/- Religion doesn't have that much impact as in "Civ5". But it does have a considerable impact on diplomacy.
+/- Culture bombs work in the same way as great general citadels.
+/- Different great persons may discover different technologies.
+/- Corporations - spread them like relligion and each corporation will have different effects. "They are mechanisms that can add substantial production to a city, at the cost of higher maintenance costs. Thus, in essence they convert gold into other basic goods (food, hammers, science, and culture)." [From Wikia]

However, there are some aspects in which "Civ4" falls behind "Civ5":

- Square tiles. Hexagon tiles are far better for strategical gameplay and layout.
- Unit stacks. I know that I will be condemned for this and for a while I missed the stacking option in "Civ 5", but, when I got used to it, I must admit that one unit-per-tile limitation actually improves the gameplay a lot. With this limitation it matters much more where you put your units. You can manage your army more easily. The city placement has a bigger impact on your attack/defence strategy. And, finally, if you play smart, you can save more of your units (sometimes even win the game without loosing any unit), whereas in "Civ4" you are bound to throw your units into the battle as cannon fodder. "Civilization 5" feels like chess in that matter. And I prefer it that way.
- Ranged units (Archers, Crossbowmen, etc.) don't have a "ranged attack" option. It is available only for siege weapons ("bombard").
- No city states. I actually like how city states provide bonuses, quests and influence the diplomacy. I think it's a better mechanic than influence points. Although, on the other hands, AI leaders in "Civ5" are completely irrational, their attitude sometimes doesn't make any sense and there is little you can do about it, whereas in "Civ4", you can at least change your civic/relligion or influence those of the AI leader.
- "Civilization 4" is harder than "Civilization 5" (although it might be a good thing for some players). In "Civilization 5", I feel comfortable on "Emperor" and with a bit of luck I can manage "Immortal" on smaller maps, whereas I struggle on "Noble" in "Civilization 4". Perhaps, it's because I haven't played "Civilization 4" in years and hadn't developed any strategy when I did.
- Technology trading. This actually makes the game rushed, unbalanced and it's much harder to make that technological gap between you and AI players. Although, there were moments, in "Civ5" multiplayer, when I wished there was this option. But, now, I see that research agreements are actually a much more balanced mechanic. Luckily, you can turn "technology trading" off in "Civ4".
- "Civilization 4" pushes you to expand early (as mush as possible). "Civilization 5" pushes you to build army early (expansion is less crucial than in "Civ4)". I don't like any of the two, but, I think, that the fact, that AI civilizations are expanding so rapidly and that you need to keep up, makes "Civilization 4" unbalanced - it's hard to maintain positive stats and to manage the cities and units. In "Civ5", you can win with less units, less initial cities and the overall pace is slower, which allows you to build your empire in a more balanced way. "Civilization III" had the same problem btw.
- No "Steam Workshop" support. But you can still use 3rd party mods.

There are probably some more differences that I've forgotten, but, in the end, I would like to say that "Civilization 4" is a great game and offers many things its successor lacks. For that reason it's worth purchasing even today ‚Äì not only for a nostalgic value, but also for the different and fun experience it offers.

My overall rating: 9/10

Also, my personal feeling is that "Civilization 5" is better in its strategical aspect, whereas "Civilization 4" is better in its "God game" aspect ‚Äì just to fool around on easier difficulties.

Civ 4 is vastly superior to the awful Civ 3. Do not be fooled by other dumb reviews saying the opposite.
The AI civs now how behave as per their leader's traits, so you can still get expansionist and aggressive opponents, but they are not ALL like that by default! It makes for a much fairer, more enjoyable game, without being forced to expand up to 100 cities before you have even got out of the iron ages!
The game is also very moddable, as you will see from some of the fully modded scenarios that come with Civ 4: BtS.
Unit strengths are now more diverse, the gulf between higher tech units and lower tech is much greater. You will now rarely see tanks defeated by pikemen!
On the negative side it has some stupid game rules. Aircraft and nukes in particular!
Neither can destroy a single unit at all. Only damage them up to a certain %age!
You will realise how fk-ing dumb fk this is when you CANNOT destroy ships with bombers - but only damage them to 50%. Once at half their HP's, all units become IMMUNE to air attacks.
Artillery using "indirect bombardment attack" has the same problem, though they can also attack "conventionally" and can destroy enemy units that way. Aircraft don't have that "conventional attack" option, only the "indirect bombardment" one. Aircraft have been the greatest DESTROYER of ships since WW2, even the game's texts say this, but in practice not ONE ship will ever be sunk by aircraft here in Civ4, not even a fishing boat!
Nukes still do not destroy cities, as in all previous Civ's. But this time they don't destroy the units garrisioned there neither. They will knock them down to just 1% strength, but that's no good, they'll be back at 100% within three or four turns! Fallout also fades away after just a dozen turns...... BULLSHIT, it should last dozens of turns at least, or until cleaned up by workers, like as in the original Civ 1!
When you find remnant "barbarian warriors" or "barbarian galleys" still entrapped in the sea ice in the map's polar regions, ie places where they cannot move units out from, nor can you send any units into, and you find that even nuclear weapons cannot destroy them....... well, you'll realise how stupid this "only damage up to xx% rule" is.
The "random generator" is also "pre-ordained". So if a bad "random" event happen, or a battle goes badly, do NOT expect to roll back to the previous turn and try again. EXACTLY the same results will happen again and again and again no matter how many times you retry!
If you see anything that tells you of an "odds for success", it's talking bllcks! Anything below 80% chance of success is actually ZERO% chance!
The new espionage system is not well thought out. The damage your spies do to the enemy is pathetic, and they'll fix it all within a couple of turns. It's not worth the effort building a strong spy network.
City production values are also too low. It can take an entire "game epoch" for some buildings/unit to finish construction!
Thankfully, I believe ALL those above negatives can be fixed by making your own modded set of game rules. How easy that is, I do not know, yet.

This is not a review of vanilla Beyond the Sword. I haven't even played the vanilla game in over a decade (and the hours I have on Steam are only a fraction of my total hours in this game, as I've been playing it since 2008 or so). Instead, I shall talk about a couple of mods available for this wonderful game - they're the real reason Civ 4 is still the best in the series.

[h1]Realism Invictus[/h1]

This mod greatly expands the content of Civ 4 and adds more realism and historical believability to it. Different civs now have more unique playstyles than before and there are a lot more techs, buildings and units to research and construct. Graphics have also been improved and offer a more pleasant visual experience, with less bright and more natural terrain textures. Unlike some other mods (Rise of Mankind or Caveman 2 Cosmos, which I'll be talking about below) this one doesn't go overboard with adding new things, though. It's a well-balanced mod that expands upon the vanilla experience but doesn't stray too far from it. And its last update was released this year (2020), so it's still being worked on.

[h1]Fall From Heaven 2[/h1]

THE fantasy mod everyone raves about. A whole lot of different civilizations, all of which have their own unique unit rosters and some of which play completely differently to the others. It also adds a magic system a la Master of Magic to the game, as well as an armageddon counter that will spawn a demonic invasion once it reaches its peak. There are several spinoffs of this one around, made by different modding teams who put their own spin on the mod's gameplay and factions. Highly recommended.

[h1]Rhye's and Fall[/h1]

The basic version of this mod is already included in the game. It lets you pick any civilization from antiquity and then lead it through the ages on a big map of Earth. New civilizations spawn at historically correct times, so if you start out as Babylon you will have to deal with a Persian invasion at some point. It's a very different experience to vanilla Civ's random map sandbox, and I find it highly enjoyable. There are some spinoff/provincial campaign submods of this, like Rhye's and Fall Europe 500-1800. Highly recommended

[h1]Caveman 2 Cosmos[/h1]

The biggest, baddest mod of them all. It adds everything. Literally everything. You guide your civilization from prehistoric caveman times to a post-scarcity hyperspace future. There are dozens of civilizations and leaders to pick from, leaders can gain experience and earn new traits rather than being stuck with their starting traits, the early game consists of exploring a wilderness populated by megafauna and hunting animals to provide your village with food, when you start out your civilization doesn't even know how to talk yet... [b]language is a technology you have to research first.[/b] There are probably a thousand different buildings to construct and units to recruit. I'm not even kidding. You can construct such lovely buildings as a toymaker's shop, florist's shop, street sweeper's office, hairdresser, wig maker... according to the developers, there are over 734 technologies in the game, and many of these techs unlock between one and a dozen buildings to construct. It also adds new gameplay elements such as waste management, pollution, crime rate, and many more things you have to manage. If you like mods that add a lot of new stuff, you will love Caveman 2 Cosmos. It's the prime example of "bigger is better".

Now excuse me, I'll have to go back to my game as Adolf Hitler of the Germans, who is currently trying to convert his neighbors to Scientology, and anyone who refuses gets terrorized by spies detonating pocket nukes in their cities (yes, this mod has [b]pocket nukes[/b]) while my [b]giraffe cavalry[/b] (yes this mod has [b]GIRAFFE CAVALRY[/b]) is patrolling my borders.

Civilization 4 was the first Civ game I ever played. It's still one of my favorites. The classic civ experience of trying to manage your little civilization and win the game by either time, domination, culture, diplomacy, religion, or space race is nostalgic, challenging, and fun for me. Accessibility for modding and creating custom maps is pretty easy to use and I've sunk time into creating various scenarios in the game. The vassal feature and other diplomacy options not really available in later games sets it apart. The only thing more I would've asked for would be to be able to play a game with all of the civilizations in game - you get to have almost all of them in the RFC mod - but you still don't get to have a game with all of the civs in any of the Civilization games thus far.  All in all, it's a good game, and I would recommend it as a classic in the Civilization series.

If you are a fan of the board game RISK --- you will thoroughly enjoy CIV IV --- A.K.A. "RISK on steroids".  In this turn based strategy game you can choose scenarios starting at different eras throughout history or carve an empire from the dawn of civilization.  In this game you settle new cities, expand your cultural borders to conquer more territory, build military units or city improvements in the city management screen, and develop relationships or enemies through diplomacy with your neighbors.  Each game is different depending on how you handle diplomacy, what technologies you research, and what kind of game strategy you decide to choose.

[h1]Follow our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/36214917/]Curator Group for more reviews[/url][/h1]
Civilization IV is, for me, the peak of the Civilization franchise. It's much more accessible and user friendly than the first 3 games, but isn't overly streamlined like the most recent games. It can be played casually and you can still get a lot of enjoyment out of it, but you can go deep into the micromanagement of it and make the game a lot more complicated, if that's how you prefer to play your strategy games. This flexibility is another of its strongest aspects, which is heightened due to the extensive modding community. It is the largest and most active modding community across the entire franchise (in my experience). There are some truly amazing mods that can completely change how the game is played and what it's about. My personal favorite would be Caveman 2 Cosmos. It has 5 times the technologies of the base game, which expands each era into its own small game of Civ. It is extremely long and adds dozens of new mechanics, so it might be too much of an overhaul for some people, although I still recommend giving it a shot.

10/10 (with Caveman 2 Cosmos mod)

Overall I recommend this game, but if there was a button for me to choose that wasn't thumbs up or down, I would. Pretty typical strategy game, with the typical goods and bads. There is a lot of depth to the potential playstyles, going with culture, war, religion, or winning through the power of being filthy rich. Lots of unit/city options for specialization, and unlike some games of this genre you can even automate a lot of production (however, the AI is pretty bad, it'll completely cut off production to increase population growth, even though you don't have the buildings to support that population, even if you tell it to specifically prioritize production). At it's core, it's a pretty solid game mechanically.

However, that solid mechanical core is exactly what makes this game a bit bad too. You have all these mechanics that YOU have to learn to do well...but the AI doesn't follow a single, solitary bit of it, and this issue isn't confined to the insane difficulty settings, where it's a bit more expected for an AI to "cheat" in order to maintain difficulty. The game gives you a list next to each leader saying what they like and dislike about you...but having 0 dislikable traits (such as being the same religion, having open borders and a lot of good trade, not having border tension, sharing common enemies) doesn't mean a thing, they'll still declare war with no given reason. You can have excellent espionage and satellite technology that let's you see every part of the map with no blind spots...just so you can actually SEE the AI spawn an army when it needs it. Turning on permanent alliances and forming one with an AI will lead to them just gifting you EVERYTHING extra they have lying around, which is nice, sure, but does go heavily against all mechanics previously learned, and weakens them often to the point where people will attack them regardless of your treaty, dragging you into wars with no real purpose.

In short this game, while fun, isn't really all that strategic in reality, because you cannot trust the information the game gives you to strategize upon. No matter how well things are with your neighbors, you may as well have not tried, because you still need to build an inordinate amount of defensive units, wasting years and gold, because your best friend will attack you out of the blue. No matter how strategically you played, having an, again, inordinate amount of units is the answer to attacking as well, because 10+ units will just appear in the third to last city you need to conquer, in a single turn. Steer clear if you wanted a game that actually rewards planning.

The main issue was simply how defence and offence were handled in the game. Defence was majorly OP. I mean, a single longbowman with 1 city defence was able to hold his own, agaisnt 3-4 units. In otherwords a city with 3 longbowman would need a army of 12 units to take, and thats without a) losing any on the way and b) not including any catapults that you would need to reduce the walls, otherwise you could add an extra 4-5 units.

In other words to take a city with 3 longbowmen and walls would require 20 units. It was such a bad design that a complete re-haul of the combat system was a main point for civ 5.

THE REVIEW:
First and foremost my playtime is far from the actual time I spend with it. Over the course of time I probably played it for 100 times as long, if not more. But I recently got the game on Steam very cheap, the reason being my old copy of the game I bought long time ago was from an old gaming site which had implemented an obnoxious yearly updated that had to be manually re-installed to "refresh" their DRM protection (or the game wouldnt run). So the current 77 hours is just from the time I bought it a few weeks ago until now.

I am recommending the game, but I really shouldn't if we are just talking about the vanilla game with no mods. The vanilla game is.. well quite frankly it's not very good. It's barebones, very predictable, with a shoddy AI. However, with mods you completely and utterly transform it into a magnificent masterpiece that truly stand the test of time. The modding community was/is especially strong with this title and incredible mods and overhauls have been created through tireless and immense devotion from talented modders. The fact that the game engine does ALLOW modders to add and change so much as they have done, does at least give the game some credit. The later renditions in the series, civ5 and civ6, are very limited in mod support and as a consequence those games have much fewer and much smaller mods. Modders weren't able to fix those games, they still suck. (but the majority of civ5 and civ6 gamers seem to be overjoyed with these games for some strange reason... I guess most gamers want dumbed down superficial gameplay. ah, but that's another story. If you don't like complexity and details I can tell you now that any civ game in it's vanilla state will probably be just what you want...).

Now that I made it clear how important mods are for this game (I wouldnt have played it without mods and I think I actually only played the game ONCE without mods, then when I started with mods I never looked back) I should mention Caveman2Cosmos mod overhaul pack (C2C) as it is insanely filled with content. I can't even start to describe just how much content it has unless you actually see it for yourself. But here's a few pointers: 13 tech eras. 13!, from "Prehistoric" era all the way up to "Transcendent" and each of those eras containing from ~50-100 technologies, which all amounts to nearly 1000 total technologies to research. Compare that to vanilla civ4's 86 (92 if you include BTS's +6 techs) total technologies...! That's the kind of grand scale C2C provides. And this trickles down into almost every area of the mod, be it units, buildings, wonders, promotions.... And many more specially designed concepts are implemented too, like hunting. Hunting animals to capture to use on your cities for bonuses and benefits is a major part of the game, especially in the prehistoric era, which is obviously very fitting. But there is also a "cover" system where units can have different cover and spotting modifiers through promotions or terrain or improvements, making for a very fun and interesting hide and seek mechanic. But enough of that, I could talk all day and night about C2C and I would only scratch the surface of what there is.... If you like details and complexity, you definitely must not miss out on C2C.

C2C official forum thread here: https://forums.civfanatics.com/threads/caveman-2-cosmos.288570/

Outside of C2C I can also recommend the Realism Invictus mod which true to its name seeks to give the player a more realistic experience. It's far from as complex or content filled as C2C, but it has its own charm and is very polished, with still a large amount content (just not the INSANE degree of content in C2C ;) ).

Realism Invictus official website here: http://www.realism-invictus.com/

The great thing is that these mods can be installed concurrently without interfering with eachother at all. A specific mod can be loaded with the game through a mod supplied batch file or you can run the vanilla game and then load the desired mod from the main menu (prompting a restart launching of the game with the mod loaded.)

A note to would-be mod users: you must play on 64bit system or else you will probably sooner or later run into a MAF error which is due to the game using too much memory for a 32bit system to handle (or maybe civ4 just wasnt optimized to handle such memory allocations on a 32bit system with so much extra content) Whatever the actual reason, a 32bit system wont work for you if you decide to install mods that boosts the amount the content more than just a little. The vanilla game doesnt run into this problem, but mods such as the two above mentioned has so much content that games will grow the memory beyond the limitations that the game can get in a 32bit system. Even on a 64bit system there is a risk that later eras can give problems if you choose to play on huge maps. Especially if you play C2C on a huge map the later modern errors are liable to produce a MAF error, even on 64bit systems. A MAF error will make your save game unable to continue because you will keep getting the error each time you end a turn, sometimes you can reload the game and get one turn more, but then the next turn will produce the error again, until finally it happens everytime you end that turn and you cannot progress anymore. However on Large maps there shouldn't be any problems no matter the era you reach or how long you play with C2C (I never had anyway, but of course I dont know the specifics of your system so I can give no guarantees you wont experience MAF's even if you do make sure to use a 64bit system and no maps larger than Large). So as long as you have a 64bit windows and do not use maps larger than Large maps then you will most likely be fine (again I give no guarantees, all can say is it works for me). If you do choose to use huge maps expect problems MAF's to begin occurring around or after Modern age. On a 32bit system expect MAF's around medieval age even on Large maps. Again, note that the vanilla game has so little content it is unlikely to have problems with 32bit systems even with Huge maps.

With Civ V, the computer wasn't smart enough to use the new combat method, which made wars boring and created situations where you could win battles against superior enemies that you really should lose against.  The developers also seemed to want to punish the players that wanted to slowly conquer the globe in a bid for world domination rather than attempting for one of the more civilized victories.  

In Civ IV, the computer can still stack units and make for a harder fought battle, global domination is still a focus of the game, the land rush for territory at the start is still important and compelling.  And, if you play it enough to get good at it, there are still the cheats you can use for raging barbarians or simply to advance the Civilizations you are playing against to make the game more compelling and the victories harder fought.

It's still the superior Civ game, the apex of the franchise before it took a turn for the worst.

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#336 out of 612)... it's time for Sins of a Civilization IV: Beyond the Sword..

The final and most ambitious of the Civilization IV expansions, Beyond the Sword is a phenomenal advancement of the Civilization formula--expanding the core game beyond the confines of Earth and into space. When Civilization tried this same trick, several years later, they simply re-skinned Civilization V and sold it as a new game, without even half so much depth or heart as Beyond the Sword--which is a total conversion of Civilization IV.

Beyond the Sword is a bit more difficult to get into now than it was during its heyday, owing mostly to the dated design of Civilization IV. Most egregious is the absence of tooltips, which exacerbates the learning curve and can make even simple tasks a bit tedious to complete. The combat mechanics also leave a lot to be desired, especially as the science fiction setting seems to lend itself more towards war than diplomacy (or maybe that's just in my head). Today, there are tons of brilliant grand strategy games set in space, but most are in real-time, and of the few that are turn-based, fewer still offer the complexity or depth of Beyond the Sword.

Note: Also played on PC, sans-Steam.
