caveman 2 cosmos. best mod ever on civ fanatics website. this basic game with c2c on it is amazing. the vanilla game stinks. out of all the games i bought i play this the most. using the c2c mod makes playing this game the same as being a god. if you set it up right all you do is watch your people slowly progress and occasionally intervene. if you ever wondered why god does certain things play this game with the c2c mod fiddle with all of the options and sit back and watch your people grow. from almost nothing into divine beings themselves. this game with the c2c mod also gives you the opportunity to take a good look at yourself and ask why did you make the choices you made in the game. realistic consequneces help to make everything in the game seem more important than it really is. do you want to know what it's like to be a god? or is god just some geek playing a game just like this and we just npc's in that game? just something to think about. using the c2c mod could easily stretch out your game over the span of quite possibly a few years. if you play it on eternity mode. that's my favorite choice for how the game plays out. nice and slow. i get to watch everything happen gradually and develop my civilisation the right way. take your time playing this game. think before you make a decision. have fun. best game ever.

PROS: 
[list]
[*] The death stack "problem" of I-III has been solved with upgrade specializations and combined arms
[*] The happiness and health systems are worked to perfection 
[*] Unique leaders per civilization create wonderfully different experiences within the same civ
[*] Corporations are like late game religions, and make for fun, flexible late gameplay
[*] The music is peerless
[*] 15 year old graphics? No problem, still good
[*] Excellent modding community, though you have to go outside the workshop
[/list]

CONS:
[list]
[*] Late game turns with large empires, especially while at war, can be exhaustively long, 20+ minutes
[*] Enemy movement on their turn is impossible to follow, very choppy, many skips
[/list]

Civilization IV : Beyond the Sword

Pros-

#1.Many civilizations to choose from

#2.Good graphics

#3.Good music and voice acting

#4.Many difficulty levels

#5.Many religions in the game

Religion does effect how some people treat each other.This is very realistic

#6.Multiple ways to win the game

#7.Custom games

I like that I can turn off barbarian and animal attacks.I know having them are realistic but I prefer to take them out.I also change other things and I like the freedom.If I could not make my own custom game then I would of rated this a 5 or 6

#8.Cool animations after you build most wonders

#9.Random events add more of a challenge

#10.Conquering a civilization that has been pissing you off is fun

#11.Cool mods to check out


Cons-

#1.Unrealistic combat in some situations

Could a tank ever be killed by some of the units in the game? Even if a tank ran out of ammo and fuel than the only way some units could kill the men inside of it would be to wait for them to exit the tank.There was certain battle winners that seemed really unrealistic.Overall the combat odds of winning a battle seemed realistic enough but I hope it is improved 


#2.Not being able to see the cities the way Total War allows you to

Compared to Total War in which you can see your city up close,Civ needs some major improvement

#3.Not upgrading the battles the way Total War has

The up close combat in Total War is far from perfect.The AI can be stupid and unrealistic but the up close combat battles are an option that Civ needs in my opinion

#4.Not enough religions and lack of religious options

I think more religions should be added.I also think being able to choose atheist,theist and agnostic should also be added


The Bottom Line -

Civilization IV: Beyond the Sword has plenty to offer strategy fans.I have spent countless hours playing it and I can make custom games very different from each other.I would say it is the best Civilization game I have ever played.I think I like more than Civ 5 and I have not played 6 yet.

I do think it needs even more options for custom games though.It just doesn't have enough options for me.

I do recommend that all strategy fans buy this but I didn't find it to be amazing or revolutionary.It is just a good turn based strategy game that can give you hours of fun.I do hope they try the total war battles it would be cool.

My 2 cents

This is a classic, and the high point of the series. Unlike later entries in the series, Civ 4 feels huge, and feels good while being huge. You can have a vast and sprawling empire and not have it feel so incredibly shitty. It actually feels great to expand your empire and found new cities and you can do it almost however you like. Not having to manually control trade routes and instead just being able to build roads for trade to go on feels much better, too. Loads and loads of mods, too, especially total conversion mods. Installing mods on steam games outside of the workshop is a bit tricky, because steam is DRM masquerading as a store, but it's not impossible and there are lots of helpful people on Civfanatics. Wholehearted thumbs up.

Everything. Everything is good about this game. Sure it's old, but this is by far the most addictive game I've ever played. And it is also the most educational one too. (I probably learned more about the world just by playing this game than I did in school, just by meeting people or building things to win the game and then going and reading about them later). For anyone who liked playing RISK the board game, or Settlers of Catan, or SIMS, or anything like those games, try playing this. It is a strategy game, but you can spend just as much time exploring and developing your lands and trading goods with neighbours as you can going to war. And while war in this game is fun, you don't even have to go to war. There are multiple ways to win the game, (for example you can found the United Nations and win through diplomacy, or you can build other world wonders and win a cultural victory. You can win by having the most land, and so on. And yes of course you can also blow your neighbours up too). Try it. :)

The hours recorded don't do justice to how much time I have put into this game, many many more days maybe even months worth of time growing up have gone into this game. It is a game that is enjoyable the more and more you play it and it rewards new strategies as well as playing to certain strengths. I have gotten to where I can win almost every time on Monarch difficulty, yet it is rewarding because it still is so challenging at times. My only complaint is that because the game was developed so many years ago, you can abuse the AI in certain ways. (For example: At war, the AI if they have catapults will always lower the wall defense, even if they could take the city with little effort, sometimes allowing you to get troops there in time to defend). But then again there is an advantage to being human I guess. I find myself playing Civ IV and Civ III more than any of the other ones. I think this is largely due to the fact that the game is simple to understand but extremely hard to master. I would love to see a redone version of Civ III or Civ IV more than I would a newer game, but those are just my thoughts. I love these games, and I will continue to play Civ IV as long as I can.

While over a decade old now, Civ 4 has a devoted fan base, and a prolific and skilled modding community. Some of the fantasy mods in the game are almost as old as the game itself, and have seen many generations of improvement. If you have the time to put in, I recommend finding the Ashes of Erebus mod on Sourceforge, transforming the game into a Game of Thrones-esque fantasy setting with a complex magic system, completely reworked tech trees and custom civilizations ranging from Giants, Hamsters and Steampunk technologists fighting alongside traditional Elves and Dwarves.

I like this game more than Civ 5, the only other Civ game I've played, mainly because it's fast and unforgiving and learning the strategy is ultimately satisfying. There's also some great mods out there to make the game harder or better to look at for example. There's also something about the beginning of the game that's addicting and makes me keep coming back to try out a new civ and a new strategy.

I've been playing this game since it came out in 2005 and likely have well over 1,000 hours on it.  It's a great game, the graphics are of course a product of their era but it's fun and infinitely playable.

I suggest the Civfanatics forums if you want to reach the full potential of this game. I am running this on a Linux system by the way, using the proton compatibility layer from Steam. There are a few minor issues in Linux Ubuntu. For example I get a black map and have to load in game to get the map properly up.

This game is great in many ways. Civ4 has a great CPU (massive range of difficulty settings), great variety of nations, maps, units and research. Then there's the Civopedia (probably spelt wrong) where you learn so much about the history of the units in real life... and the rectangular squares are brilliant. A game I'd recommend to so many people.

Back in 2008 a friend of mine had bought me this game for me at a used game store, at the time I have never laid eyes on a 'strategy' game, let alone a 4X strategy game. At first it felt like this game was impenetrable, but I stood up all night regardless throwing myself at this game until things started to click. Some of my fondest memories was spending late night hours with a bottle of crystal light, venturing further and further into the future where I would eventually walk away with a victory. I would go so far as to say this game has brought me some of my fondest memories, perhaps some of that is due to a time and place of when it took place, but it was special none-the-less.

So that's why I bought Civilization 5 almost immediately, and something was different in how I felt about Civilization afterwards. Chasing that high I got with Civilization 4 actually made me dislike 5... I still had fun sometimes but it felt like a chore. I was sticking with 5 because I enjoyed 4 so much so I had decieved myself into thinking I was having fun. I rarely finished a game. 

Jumping back into it a little more than a decade later, a similar rush of excitement came over me when I joined a lobby that didn't immediately disconnect or where everyone left. Seeing the map and units on the map gave me a sense of joy and familiarity... the only other strategy game that has even came close to that was Endless Legend. For a while, playing Amplitude's game brought me back closer to the original Civ 4 days, so I became a primarily Endless player for a short bit. The difference to me was that while Endless Legend had interesting ideas, I felt like once I saw those ideas in play, I wasn't too tempted to repeat that process. Whereas Civ 4 felt timeless in a way, because of the similarities between factions, they were more open to be played differently I guess.

Anyways... this is just me showing my respects for a game that has introduced me to strategy games in general. It's more for me than anything else, writing a quick thing about a game that has meant so much to me for so long. The other games I currently have accompanying this one is Offworld Trading Company, Chaos Reborn, and Koikatsu Party. I'm currently chasing that next high in discovering a new game so I'm cautiously looking for the next best thing. I'm honestly uncertain if that'll happen in my current mindset, I might have to move on for the sake of discovery. Or I could just make myself at home.

I remember playing civ 1 and civ 2 long ago and i got civ 5 before i got this game when i bought the complete civ iv.

first, it isnt properly explained how civ 4 works: if you bought it complete like mine, the expansions are not installed by installing the base game - each of the installs is actually separate, so each succeeding expansion version includes any previous dlc plus the base game. this means to play all of civ 4 and expansions, you only need to install the beyond the sword version which was the final expansion and so includes everything.

this game is different in many ways to civ v - the map isnt hex its squared, which i think is not as good as civ v; but this game the combat is very different, with unit stacking. you can get some pretty impressive battles as a result, where a huge stack of mixed units tries to take a city from another huge stack or from a small stack of highly experienced units. this makes the experience very different - not better necessarily, just i think some will prefer civ v and some this game.

diplomacy is different also, i have other civs as vassals for example. while that means you are their boss, it also means 2 other things - when you get into war so do they, and if someone attacks them, you have a moral obligation to defend them. this complicates diplomacy in an interesting way.
. 
some units behave differently, the one most springing to mind is the privateer: in civ 5 it captures enemy ships but is always clear who owns it. in civ 4 it has hidden ownership - so you can blockade cities and sink ships with them and nobody will know who to declare war on. you can use it to enter enemy territory without risking war.

all in all this game is in some ways more complex, and others just different to civ 5 and just for the change of pace its worth buying this game, particularly if you get the complete civ iv with all expansions. there are lots of mods you can find for the game, and scenarios that it comes with. very enjoyable game.

Civilization 4 broke the chain. I could win Civ4. Managed economies, production chains, monetary power houses. I had it all.

RNG IS THE WORST

It ruins games strategically, all that effort, all that work WASTED because of a lethal Rng roll. I'm not entirely against rng in general, procedural generation is a blessing for maps, enemies, missions, etc! And you can't just lose a tank to a spearman because of random chance. One of the best Civilization games, with one of the best Civilization expansions. Although it may now seem  a little dated when compared to the newer entries, it was a landmark entry in the series that added a number of features seen regularly in the successive Civilization games: multi-model units, religion, and depth in systems of government perhaps most analogous to the civics system in Civilization VI. 

The game itself is purely strategic empire building; the player generally starts out with a handful of units under their control with which to create an empire (although, with Beyond the Sword, accelerated starts, in which the player begins with a developed nation, are an option). From these humble beginnings a player must manage what little resources they have to grow. Production takes place in cities, which produce both units (the various units can create new cities, fight other player's units and capture their cities, or build infrastructure) and buildings (which affects how a nation grows in size and in sophistication, gathers wealth, distributes resources, and produces units). More advanced units and buildings are unlocked as players research new technologies. Technologies also unlock civic choices (think style of government) and religion, which impacts your nation's domestic policies as well as your international standing.

All of these actions can lead to a myriad of ways to win the game, which reflect a number of playstyles- you can colonize or conquer the world, convert everyone to your religion, be the first to send colonists to distant space, or through shrewd diplomacy run the world through a global congress. The onus is on the player to determine how they play and win the game, with arguably more potential means to do so than in the previous or successive games.

Civilization IV manages to strike a balance between domestic management, strategic events, and a dynamic world in a way that prevents any one facet of empire-building to eclipse the others, and to advance the pace of gameplay at a rate that, for the most part, keeps it from becoming tedious (sometimes early game can develop slowly, but as a player expands their holdings, it quickly moves past any potential stagnation).

Beyond the Sword adds an additional smattering of content that deeply impacts how the game plays. While the most visible aspect of the expansion is the addition of a number of new civilizations, a large amount of content is added that expands late-game action, especially in the areas of espionage, global diplomacy, and trade. Features like the addition of corporations and random events have a way of radically altering the direction a player may take in a game.

And all this is before one mentions mods. Civilization IV (and Beyond the Sword in particular) has a plethora of high-quality mods available, which, once downloaded and installed, can be easily started in-game while picking a scenario. The focus of the mods run the gamut, too. Fictional scenarios abound: Fall from Heaven II puts the player in a dark fantasy setting, while Dune Wars is a reimagining of Frank Herbert's influential science fiction classic. And if authenticity is more your style, mods like Realism Invictus attempt to provide historical accuracy (among a host of other features), and Caveman 2 Cosmos attempts to follow the human story from its infancy as "cavemen" to being the transcendent masters of the universe.

But above all else, Civilization IV is about freedom- the freedom to run a nation any way you wish; the freedom to be an influential leader, a wealthy trader, a passive pacifist, or a cruel tyrant; and the freedom to do all of this with impunity. It is about the freedom to tag alongside icons of history and repeat their triumphs and failures, or to forge your own destiny and leave your own legacy. And taking the various pre-installed scenarios (exponentially so if one would download mods) into account, it can even give one the freedom to lead their people as a hero against a fallen god, to crush one's enemies with their hordes of giant robotic war machines, or to explore the furthest reaches of the galaxy.

In Civilization IV, with the Beyond the Sword expansion, the choice is up to the player. The question is- will you take it?

By far the best game I have ever had the opportunity to play. Civilization IV: Beyond the Sword is the crown jewel of the Civilization series, with a quality of play unparalleled by any other 4X turn-based strategy game.

Several of its advantages include:
-Fully Optimizable Gameplay
-Many combinations of strategic options for civilization optimization
-Multiple leaders allow for civilizations to play completely differently
-Rational AI Diplomacy
-Rewards the player for doing well
-Vibrant MP community
-Many Mods: Fall From Heaven 2, Rhye's and Fall of Civilization, Dune Wars, etc.

The best of all Civilizations, it stuck to its origins of being a strategic empire-management game. Civilization IV has an extremely high replay value: I had a non-Steam copy for years, and have logged at least 500+ hours on Civ4 and its mods before deciding to purchase a digital copy.

I -HIGHLY- recommend this game!

And if you do get a copy, let me know and we can play multiplayer sometime!

The mod: Fall From Heaven 2 makes Civ IV Beyond the Sword still worth playing

Fall From Heaven is an interpretation of Simtex's turn based strategy, Master of Magic (MoM). MoM with its artefact editor was very configurable with great replay value. Fall from Heaven stretches the magic metaphor with all kinds of cool, playable options.
Race world spells, alternate magic progression trees, evil / neutral / good aligned races, evil / neutral / good avatars. 
How great is it to play evil, own the good magics and summon the avatar of Good - thus denying him to a good race (or vice versa). 
Or discover the technology that leads to the Shadow unit + the Shrine of Sirona. A Shadow can chip away at the units of your enemy and constantly be healed. 
How about capturing an end game boss - Acheron the Red Dragon spawns after about 100 turns - chip away at it with a few units then use a Beastmaster (I used a Shadow). 
Endless joy from dungeons that spawn baddies - park a unit (or hero) near and manage the xp. Even better than dungeons are the indestructible locations such as Guardian of the Pristin Pass. Don't build cities there!
The soundtrack by Nox Arcana is exceptional, the civilopedia is comprehensive - but there are little things you keep discovering. The mod works fine on the Civ IV engine and does an excellent job of conjuring up the sense of difference and the strange (but oddly beautiful) of Simtex's Master of Magic. I can only scratch the surface with this review so check around on the net - there's plenty more info - and yes I sometimes crank up Simtex's MoM.
Fall From Heaven 2 mod for Civ IV BtS is endlessly replayable - give it a try, you'll be hooked.

Different, flexible - many routes to victory.

After playing thousands of hours on this game (mostly offline), I can offically say this is the best "empire" building strategy game there is. It reallly is a must have if you like the total war series, EU IV and HOI mixed with that civilization vibe of the testing and changing of time. While less tactical than the latter versions of Civ, it holds it's own in feeling like a true civilization builder, somewhat lost in V and VI.

The multiplayer is still active, however you may need to join up on a Civ IV BTS steam group and send out a few friend requests. You need cordination between players due to the long hours of each game and generally most won't play unless offered. 

As a side note, I really suggest going on the website Civfanatics for Civ IV BtS (link below) and downloading the mod/map GEM (Giant Earth Map). You won't get a better Earth based "building a civilization" experience, which is what I and many geogrpahic/geopolitical buffs love. This map/mod alone made a couple of friends buy the game, so it's worth looking at.

https://forums.civfanatics.com/threads/welcome-to-giant-earth-map-gem.276594/

Civilization IV is a grand turning point aesthetically and graphically, but this addition would change the fate of the game's popularity.

Beyond the Sword is a great expansion as it brung a lot more units, and a lot of helpful addition in control the government of your civilization, along with introducing some re-defined conditions for revolts and wars. It also expanded on the Civilization IV community, specifically modding and redefinitions of the series. This essentially expanded upon the 1700s to the 2000s and beyond, introducing a few more mods intended for this expansion.

Nonetheless, this expansion proves worthiness in my library as it brung Civilization IV more accessible to the public and expanded upon a lot of features and even added some of its own. I love this and Civilization IV.

To this day, I don't think a game will continue to engage me like Civilization IV. Some of the changes in following editions were steps backward, and the ones before it, though excellent, were not nearly as good. The world-building, the items and units you could pit against each other in amazing ways, and most especially the mods you could use, all made it my favorite. Even now, and probably for decades to come, I would rather play Fall From Heaven II than most of the new games that are supposed to be cutting edge and beautiful. This is a true work of art.

Both the best Civilization game ever (played the retail version for thousands of hours before getting it on Steam), and the best modding platform ever. No other game has seen mods as epic as Fall from Heaven II (and its numerous derivatives), and Rhye's and Fall of Civilizations and Rise of Mankind.

Other game companies should learn from Firaxis and open the source code of a part of their game so modders can really add new functionality without dumb hacks.

Other modding communities would do well to learn from the culture of modmodding in the Civ community, where people build upon the work of others and improve and refine it endlessly. A true community instead of a juxtaposition of bickering inflated egos.

It also wins my personal award for the most epic and fitting title screen music of all times, Baba Yetu.

I was introduced to the Civilization series via Civilization Revolution on the Xbox 360. I loved the fact that I could play leaders from the greatest nations and empires the world had ever seen, building an empire that can stand the "test of time". It is because of CivRev that my Brother and I went to the nearest Walgreens to purchase a cheap Civ game at the time(this was when Civ 5 was still fresh). Armed with $20, I bought my steam card, went home, and made a purchase, a purchase that would forever change my life. I should note that I was a noob back then, and bought vanilla Civ 4 first, but I do not regret it, hearing the sweet sound of Baba Yetu grace my eardrums, oh what sweetness. It all went downhill(or uphill) from there. Civ 4----->Civ 4 Warlords------->Civ 4 Beyond the Sword(BTS), that is the order I went to purchase. I can say that Civ 4 BTS was the pinnacle of excellence for me, and remains as such today( Civ 5 plz bring back one more turn for multiplayer :( ). I was able to play 1000 turns with my bro on one game, a testament to the playability of Civ 4 BTS. The ai can be shabby at times, but when its good( Peter the Great of Russia), you can get wars on the magnitude of WWII in the game. I personally reccomend this game for anyone looking for the quintessential civ experience.

TL;DR: What are you waiting for?!?! GET THIS GAME!!!!!

single player & hotseat games: game rarely crashes & the gameplay is above-average & fun

online multiplayer: game crashes so often it's basically unplayable. most games end in crashes. when you're at war with someone & you're playing simultanious turns the gameplay feels really cluncky in several different ways (i could write a huge paragraph about this but i'm doing this review for free & i'm lazy).
      another complaint i have is the lack of support for the online multiplayer community. anyone who's serious about playing online is forced to play in the community-organized unofficial league - which is fairly well-organized for something that people organize for free - the lack of official organized multiplayer support from the company is pathetic. even free games like league of legends have official ladders and rankings! oh and another thing league of legends has is a functioning online multiplayer game that doesn't crash! for free!

in conclusion: if you don't care about the online multiplayer games i do recommend the game. if you're like me and you want to play online multiplayer games i do not recommend this game. i thought about asking for a refund because the game is so buggy, but i changed my mind, i only paid $12 for this and i guess the single player & hotseat games are worth $12 to me.

Most amazing game of all time. 

I easily have several thousands of hours maybe even tens of thousands in all civ titles together playing it since civ 1.

But civ 4 is the best in terms of depth, replayability and strategies. Its not as dumbed down as civ 5 and has many ways to win the game not just war.

Edit:
To add a little depth to this review, compare the mod features of civ 5 and 4 and you will easily see how superior Civ 4 still is even without Steam Workshop Support. 

- Civ 4 has Multiplayer Mods. Still not happy? 
- Civ 4 vanilla has a working AI, want more?
- Civ 4 Ai can be modded to kick you in the butt unless you are a freakin PRO! More?
- Civ 4 has many ways too win and each can be played for equally...
- Civ 4 offers small civs a debth and playability you cannot get in civ 5 it is actually pretty damn well balanced. Since with small civs you can outtech bigger guys like crazy... he attacks with stacks of doom 4x your size? Who cares his Swordsmen are no match for your riflemen...done that dozens of times...
- Civ 4 has a well balanced techtree with rounded civics that work like a charm beside it. You can stack your bonusses to match your preferred way of winning. Tech-crazy, Culturewhore, Militarist, Space-Alien-Weirdo...and so on. 

Ever wanted to get diplomacy to be transparent in 5? Me too...never really worked. In Civ 4 it is transparent, you can actually rely on the information in diplomacy. Are those pesky civs getting on your nerves...mod it, mute them, play in peace and calm :) 

Alright so the only downside for some might be the stack of doom, but if you rely on that vs a skilled player you can probably kiss your stack goodbye anyway... so, in MP a non issue if you know what you are doing. In SP, well... it actually is not a clickfest like civ 5..."hey your 500000 units need to move...even though the entire map is already filled with units, but please do..."

Hands down...Civ 4 >>>> Civ 5 all the way except in graphics :)

With civ 6 on the market now for a while and the first DLC also available i still stand by my review. Civ 4 is by far the best title in the series so far. Civ 6 just never really has much action, its Civ City more like a sim city in civ clothing. You build and build and build never really action and if you do attack the AI is so freakin bad at basically the entire game, its just another tedious boring repetetive task. Sadly the only real action you can have in Civ 6 is religious wars, the rest is just not good. Remember Panzer General? Thats how turn based 1 unit per tile tactical battles should look like, but civ 6 is too small for that. A city has no real surrounding land its just city, minimal distance city, minimal distance city...not much tactics on near to no land possible. If you up the minimal distance to 5-7 (mod) its getting better however tech progression is also way too fast. You build a few units you can already start building the new type...and so on. Tech progression too fast, wars to boring, constantly building some upgrades boring trade mechanics, boring religion, boring culture...i am slowly losing hope with the game designers at firaxis. It was once GRAND Strategy now its more like dumbed down to tactical warfare between production centers. Not much grand strategy anymore in sight. Better play Europe Universalis IV or Stellaris or Civ 4 :)

I find it poetic that Civilization IV is a game about building a civilization that "stands the test of time" because, as a game, it has managed to do just that and more. After nearly 13 years since its initial release, Civ IV has established itself as one of the 4X genre's classic titles, taking its honored place next to other giants like Master of Orion and Alpha Centauri. Chalk all this up to the hordes of devoted fanboys if you must. Or the fantastic modding community. Or the perceived inferiority of later titles in the series. But I'm still of the opinion that this game has succeeded on its own merits. Even over a decade later, its mechanics still hold up to scrutiny. They're simple and abstract, but deceptively complex--one look at a Deity run on YouTube, and you'll understand what I mean. Granted, the graphics are a bit dated in 2018, and some still shudder at the thought of the infamous "doomstack." Warfare has been (and always will be) a weakness of the series, but Civ IV eschews tactical depth in favor of sheer breadth. Neither Civ V or Civ VI gives you the epic sense of scale that Civ IV delivers when you reach a late game war and slam dozens of units into each other. And at the risk of offending naysayers, the warfare in Civ IV is still some of the best in the series. War is less tactical and more logistical. Winning requires planning, grand strategy, and proper allocation of resources, not finesse. This kind of approach feels better for a game that purports to cover the entire history of the human race. The game makes warfare a function of empire. You feel like a ruler sending nameless soldiers to their deaths, not a general commanding a single army. It's this sense of distance that the later Civs lack. Empire building games do not mix well with tactical wargames. Rather than succeeding as either, Civ V and VI turn out to be poor attempts at both--subpar wargames and subpar empire building games. In the end, Civ IV turns out to be a much more focused experience. It knows what it's trying to do, and it does it effortlessly. 

Whatever you may say about warfare, Civ IV is still king as far as the "management" and "expansion" sides of the game are concerned. One problem the Civilization series has always had trouble addressing is the problem of controlling expansion. How can we limit growth in a way that feels natural and rewarding to the player, while also leaving room in the late game for sprawling empires? It's a difficult question, and Civ titles rise and fall on the answers they give. Civ IV's answer is by far the best in the series, and it comes with three very basic principles. 1. Science is tied to commerce yield. Using a percentage slider, the player controls how much of their commerce they want committed to science and how much they want committed to gold. 2. Cities have a maintenance cost which depends on their distance from the capitol and how many total cities are in your empire. 3. Cities initially cost more gold in maintenance than they make in commerce. Together, these three mechanis require the player to take a balanced approach toward expansion. Expand too slowly, and you'll lose out on the early game land grab. Expand too quickly, and you'll ruin your economy, forcing your research to grind to a halt and causing your units to go on strike. Each city, as the Civ IV veteran Sulla once said, is an "investment." Early on, new cities are weak and are a burden your empire has to bear. But if you keep developing them, building and working cottages, they can eventually support themselves. Establish a strong enough economic base wth a few core cities, and you'll have the ability to control dozens of cities in the mid-late game. It's a fantastic system, and still, I would argue, the best the series as seen so far.

Yeah, but it's 2018. We've got Civ VI now. Civ IV is old hat. It's dated, it's UI is clunky, and there's just no reason to play it anymore. Au contraire, my friend. Whatever the game may now lack in modern amenities, it makes up for with timeless mechanics and peerless depth. This is a game, to the detriment of every other aspect of your life, that will keep you glued to your seat well into the wee hours of the morning. If you have friends to play with, this is a game that will surprise you with escalating borders, Cold Wars, stunning betrayals, and the occasional nuke (not that I would know anything about that). This is a game that will test your capabilities, especially on the higher difficulties.

This was the first Civ game I ever played and I was about 13 or 14 at the time. A fantastic game for the series, Civilization 4 Beyond the Sword improves the base game in so many ways it will forever be a must have expansion for this classic. The game run's smooth and with little to no bugs, and there is never a dull game if you love the Sid Meir series. The base game improved with a variety of new units, buildings, and civilizations that are all a blast to play and add a new flare to the game which makes it feel fresh. Classic Civ at it's finest. 

The game also has some of the most diverse and incredible scenario's to ever grace a civ game. Not only have they pulled scenarios from some of the best old mod of their time, such as Ryse and Fall and Fall from Heaven, but also a host of unique scenarios that almost feel like DLC within a DLC. Next War adds an entire new era and story allowing archology cities and clone armies to devastate the world while Road to War throws you into the war torn WWII era Europe and Pacific. They even added 2 scifi mods, one a traditional 4X space empire game and a Turn Based game controlling a team of cyborgs. These are only a few of the numerious scenarios they have added and your playtime will rise exponentially as you play each scenario for hours on end. This DLC is more like a dozen smaller games put together and packaged at an insanely low price. If there is any selling point you should follow in my review, it's simply this. 

Beyond the Sword is perhaps one of the best DLC to ever be sold for Sid Meir's epic series, perhaps 4X games in general. A DLC that takes numerous unique takes of the game and makes for endless fun.

You know, it doesn't matter which one of these Sid Meiers Civilization games you play, they are ALWAYS conquest games. You inevitably have to build a huge military in order to stop the computer players from attacking you, and then MAYBE, you can try and play for one of the other victory conditions. I have yet to have found any of them that allow for anything but. I just quit a game because 3 out of 6 computer opponents all attacked me. One of them managed to march 3 absurdly huge stacks through 3 other computer opponents to do so. This is NOT a reasonable design. This is a Firaxis game flaw that has been woefully apparrent in every one of their titles. Instead of creating an A.I. that is capable of defining it's own goals, the A.I. is designed to attack the human player, period. They never got past that. I can't tell you the number of games I have played and quit because the A.I., instead of following a strategy that would actually be in their best interest, has moved settlers across the map just to settle next to me, the human player. Obviously the team at Firaxis simply cannot figure out after 20 years of game design how to create an A.I that is capable of actually playing a competent game without having to resort to game cheats and silly decision algorithms

Occasionally, along comes a game more demanding than the most lusty of succubi; a game that will truly suck the essence out of you, and you love every minute of it. Civilization 4 was such a game; from the moment you played your first turn, you knew it would claim far more of your time and energy than you were sure you had to give. Just one more turn? No, just one hundred more. And now that the latest expansion has dropped, it's time to re-evaluate your schedule once again.

Before we launch straight into all the new stuff, let's get the game's most noticeable flaw out of the way: Leonard Nimoy is no longer the voice for the game's pithy quotations. And since the tech tree has been considerably changed up, you'll be hearing Sid Meier's voice, and not Nimoy's very early in the game. Sid's a nice guy and all, but he's no Mr. Spock.

The expansion brings with it a host of changes, additions, and re-balances of Civilization 4's old formula. The benefits of the previous expansion, Civilization 4: Warlords, are rolled right in as well. Among the new systems are the espionage system, the corporation system, an advanced start system, and an army of new combat options. This is before we even look at all the new scenarios and mods that come packed on the disc.

Espionage makes for an interesting addition to the game. Unlike the somewhat awkward spy unit of pre-expansion Civ 4, the re-worked espionage system provides for a variety of different options. By spending espionage points, which are generated much as research points are, you can work on counter-espionage, foment rebellions, gather information, attempt to steal technologies, sabotage buildings in opponents' cities, influence local civics and religion, or even poison the local watering hole. Most of these require you to send a spy along to a target city, but there are still some passive benefits to building up espionage points, most of which are just gaining inside information on your foes' activities. The espionage system doesn't really require you micromanage carefully, so it's a pretty rewarding system all around. While you shouldn't be expecting to watch James Bond murder his way through the Soviet Union to make certain your civilization comes out ahead, it's nice to know he's on your side.

Excuse me a moment, I have to conquer Mongolia.

[3 hours later] Crap, it's that late already? Alright, well, let's talk about one of the other new systems quick ‚Äì the random world events. The addition makes a lot of difference to the game, and they're worked in amazingly well, frequently playing off of the events that are already ongoing in the game. Random events pop up due to wars between civilizations of different religions, over-farming, failed royal marriages, or just plain chaotic weather patterns. In a lot of respects, the random events are reminiscent of Galactic Civilizations 2, though they generally feel more balanced and less arbitrary.

Some of the new systems don't go over as well, though. The corporate system in Civilization 4: Beyond the Sword presents an almost nightmarish window into our own corporate structures. Founding a corporation is an interesting proposition, as it may very well harm you more than it benefits you. Corporations can potentially generate massive profits, but they take a great person, access to specific resources, and a fair amount of startup capital to get off the ground. Even after that, they can end up costing a lot to maintain, and getting rid of them is hard. 

Spread a branch office to your foe, however, and suddenly the maintenance burden is lessened, because your neighbor is now shouldering some of it. It's a weird, and eerily accurate, process, where frequently no one but the corporation really profits much. When you feng shui your trade routes, resources, expenditures, and diplomatic relations just right, however, corporations can generate an impressive amount of income ‚Äì finding and maintaining those balances is the trick, and it's not a simple one. Overall, corporations can be far more trouble than they're really worth, so players that aren't trying to eke every last benefit out of the game should really just stay away from 'em.

The combat refinements - including some considerable changes to artillery units - change up warfare in some interesting ways. The new specialized units bring some flair, and can help define some civilizations' preferred ages. Likewise, the new rulers (and in the case of Rome, a change in the ruler) also help spice things up in some interesting ways, and help to provide an even more varied experience. The new changes and additions help the game's replay value immensely ‚Äì though it's not as though it was needed in the first place.

Hang on, Egypt's getting uppity again...

[Another 3 hours later] Well, I'm happy to report that the pharaohs have made friends with my cannon balls. A few rounds through their fancy stone walls, and suddenly we're the best of buds again! Hatshetsup was positively grinning when she heard I wasn't going to put holes in the roof of her palace ‚Äì but it's not cause she asked me real pretty, it's because she always serves the best beer at her diplomatic functions.

The A.I. in Civilization 4 has been revamped immensely with the new expansion ‚Äì for once, you can't win the game just by keeping up with the science and agreeing to the occasional demand. When I first took up Civilization 4, I got into the habit of playing on "Emperor" difficulty level and doing alright for myself, but Beyond the Sword has forced me to scale back to "Noble" to break even, and "Warlord" to do well for myself. Between the new complications and the much cleverer A.I. opponents, I've found the game to be a renewed challenge, and a heck of a lot more fun. Given that the game was already siphoning off shreds of my very soul to power its dark simulations, I fear I might need the services of a preacher before I'll rid myself of this game. What's worse is that I'm not even clear I'll want to get that exorcism.

Getting away from all that's new to the gameplay, the expansion also comes packed with a variety of mods and new scenarios. Some are great. Some are really quite bad. There's a total conversion packaged with the game that's frankly terrible; it attempts to be some kind of tactical RPG, but ultimately comes off as a clunky turn-based strategy game with ugly units. Though it's interesting to see what can be done with the platform that Civilization 4 was built upon, it's a poor addition to the expansion. There's also a fantasy total conversion packed in, which fares reasonably, though will likely not distract you much from the main game. The varying new scenarios and little mods add some extra amusement to the game, especially the Next War mod, which expands into futuristic, sci-fi technologies.

Overall, Civilization 4: Beyond the Sword presents a lot of additions to what was already a great game. It's a good expansion, and capitalizes a great deal on fixing some of the weaknesses of the original. That said, the expansion doesn't do anything that will make someone who did not already enjoy Civilization games dance for joy. The expansion is absolutely great.
With out a doubt I have spent many happy hours playing Civ4, and many more with the "Fall from Heaven 2" Civ 4 mod. I would encourage anyone to try this game out.

The game still looks good inspite of it's age, something that really helps it in this regard is how in the eraly game units will look different depending on what part of the world they come from, the faces of the various world leaders are expressive and really nice to look at.

The combat in the game starts off pretty simple as mostly just rock paper scissors until the ages move on and new tech is made on these fronts, becoming more complicated with artillery and aircraft being thrown in to the mix.

Building an empire is fun, as populations rise and cities and buildings are constructed the appearance of said cites change  in size with the various buildings being visable inside them.

Researching technology is a neat experiance; every time you have completed on you will be given a lovingly narrated qoute and a short description of what you accomplished, and after certain techs are resaerched you will enter a new era that will be accompanied by a change in the ambience music will change along with the asthetics of your cites to signify the age your people live in.

Espionoge mixes things up quite a bit, it gives you opportunites to see what your friends and rivals are resaerching and with enough intelligence you can do everything from poisoning the water hole to learning every single last move the target of your spies is making.

Wonders are great buildings and monuments that offer special bonuses such as The Great Wall, which will prevent barbarians from entering certain parts of your borders, The Oracle, wich will give you a free tch of your choosing, and The Taj Mahal, which gives you a golden age- a event that lasts a number of turns which will give boosts to virtually everything.

Another thing that can occur is the creation of Great People: Great Builders, Great Prophets, Great Merhcants, Great Generals, Great Artists, Great Scientists, and Great Spies. These guys can give you a variety of different boons from starting a corperation, expanding your borders, giving more experience to some of your units, and giving you a free tech.

You can manage you system og government from it's humble beginnings of tribal barbarism to slavery, police states, free speech, state property, theocracy, etc. These can vary in terms of expense but can also effect what kind of special events that can occur along with how other nations view your country.

Diplomacy is another thing that is simple at first but becomes far more complicated over time, between wars, religion, charity, various events, actions made by your friends, and many, many, other factors can change how the leaders of the world view you- or even how your own people see you.

I think above all others however in importance is the world maps, randomly generated that still manage to retain a sense of organization and beauty that are never the same, your experience will be different every time you play.

There are many other details that I think should be learned from playing or have been described by others, but it is mostly for the reasons I have described above that I have nominated this game for the Test of Time Award.
Still one of the best Civ games.  Who does not love the giant stack of doom?   Great game to network on your old computers.

Once upon a time, this was the best Civilization game available - for a time, even after the release of the newer Civilization V, people would call this title the best.

I'm unsure if I agree anymore, but out of personal experience, the title is tied between this game - with gamey, but believeable AI, and tons of mods that change the game in many interesting ways, and Civ V after all expansions and patches, more accessable and 'different'.  Still, Beyond the Sword is the definitive Civilization IV experience, with new technologies filling out the tree, more civilizations, and even new leaders for many - and mods are available such as the ever-popular Fall from Heaven 2, of which a supplied BtS scenario is a prequel to!

All said, I've played this since it was on a play/install disc set, and it still stands up.  You honestly can't go wrong with this if you're a fan of empire-building 4X games.

It's my honest and sincere belief that Civ4, when played with both its official expansions, is the perfect strategy game. I have a lot of trouble getting into most 4X games, even turn-based ones, but what I think makes this game far better, than, say, Galactic Civilizations 2, is that it's complex enough to give rise to various strategies, game styles and outcomes, but you're still presented with enough detail that you can look at your civilization, its cities and its individual units and find out exactly why they're unhappy, or unsuccessful, or unprofitable.

Games like Galactic Civilizations 2 hide the formulas that govern your civilization under the hood, and playing them ends up feeling more like SimCity than Risk or chess: you simply find yourself responding to events as they happen, without a clear understanding of how your actions will affect even your own civilization. Civ4 throws that sort of design out completely--it's detailed, but not ridiculously so (like, say Master of Orion 3, where you feel like you're playing a spreadsheet), and knowing that its design is good, it doesn't feel obligated to hide the details.

Civ IV is my most played game ever, and a pinnacle of the strategy genre. I have installed it on every computer I have owned since it came out. The Steam play time reflects that I played from my CD-ROM copy of CIV 4 complete until recently when my install discs became incompatible with Windows 10. I feel that the Civ 4 gameplay is the most balanced and addictive of Civ 4 series games, with strong ai, diplomacy, building, expansion, religion, commerce, and war all providing great depth that makes playing just one more turn addictive. In my opnion, only the great Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri has comparable all around strengths and innovations for its time, Moreover, Civ 4 has given me unparalleled replay value because it is the most modable Civ game.  Besides the usual tweaks of the vanilla game on can find in Civ 5, Civ 4's structure enabled the creation of many complete overhaul mods that transformed CIv 4 with new gameplay and graphics, including historical, fantasy, and sci-fi mods. For example, in my opinion, the Civ 4 fantasy mod, Fall From Heaven 2, remains of one of the best 4x strategy fantasy pc games ever made. 

Civ IV, however, does show its age when compared to more refined interface of Civ V. Civ 4's maps of square titles and battles with stacks of units on the same tile, also give a less sophisticated first impression. However, when I compare the gameplay between Civ 4 and Civ 5, I find Civ 4 AI is usually more challenging, sophisticated, and strategically effective than in Civ 5, with regard to both combat and non-combat activities alike.

Install Civ 4 complete (Civ IV, Civ IV Warlords, and Civ IV Beyond the Sword) and join the addiction!

Note: I have reviewed Civ 4 and its expansions as a single game.

if you want an enjoyable empire building game, get Civ5 with the expansions (where you can actually maximize on every aspect of the game in one match...yes, there is not as many features in civ5 as civ4, however they flow together SOOOO much more smoothly, you can play a game on diety (the hardest setting), and with enough experience, you CAN lead in culture, science, happiness, religion, city size, army size, basically actually create a "world superpower" unlike in civ4 where you basically are "only culture" or "only science" or "only military" etc etc, civ5 gives you much more realistic wars as theres no ridiculous unit stacking where you have all your units in one square to build one unkillable unit, in civ5 you actually HAVE to use movement strategies, and the layout of the land to win wars, not just send your one unit that takes next to no damage, and kills everything in one hit. i cannot comprehend the appreciations of civ4 when theres civ5  that actually makes you want to play. where as civ4 just makes me want to hit alt-f4 and play ANY other game in my library (and yes, ive tried to make myself enjoy civ4 as empire building games are my favourite style of genre. bottom line, Civ5 is infinitely times greater than civ4.

[h1]Civilization IV: Beyond The Sword[/h1]

The following review will focus first on Civilization IV as a whole, then on the expansion "Beyond the Sword".

[b]Civilization IV[/b]
Civilization IV was the first game of the Civ-series to go 3d, for better or for worse. The graphics are in fact atrocious compared to the newer Civ 5, and even Civ 3, with its 2d isometric graphics and heavy reliance on shades of brown. But as any fan of the TBS-genre will tell you; graphics are secondary to everything else.

You may ask yourself "why invest in Civ 4 when Civ 5 and BE is out?". Well, apart from having better graphics and adding [spoiler](and taking away)[/spoiler] certain features, there aren't many differences between these games. Some of the most important differences (or improvements as some will call them) are the limitation on movement and stacking in Civ 5. One may argue that limitations compared to older versions are negative, but the point would be moot when faced with "the stack of doom". So yes, at first glance, the newer games are better. There are however saving graces for Civ 4: Plenty of advanced and interesting mods, as well as a (more) stable multiplayer, the latter of which is laughable in Civ 5.

[b]Beyond The Sword[/b]
BtS is arguably the largest expansion to any of the Civ games, and a must-have if you want to use mods, as most of them now require it to work. It adds quite a few new features, including, but not limited to:
[list]
[*]Ten (10) new civs, as well as 6 new leaders for existing civs.
[*]Corporations: The religion of business.
[*]Random events: FUN
[*]Lots of new game rules and options, to help customize your experience.
[/list]

In conclusion: If you like the civilization-games, but don't care about graphics, or don't like the limitations of Civ V, or like Civ but want it to be more advanced with certain mods, or just want to be able to play multiplayer for more than 10 minutes without having problems; i would suggest grabbing Civ IV with BTS as soon as possible.

400 hours of Civ IV later, I can still recommend this to you, I have not gone insane. It's a classic turn-based empire game with real charm, character and a grammy winning theme song. Voiced by Lenard Nimoy, and emblazoned with the Sid Meier's logo, this game is almost a must own for any self respecting human being.

Although, some people might think that this game is slow and boring. And yes, if you play on marathon mode, or long mode or even normal mode, you can satisfy a whole week's worth of game time in just one save file.

But, and this but is a Nicki Minaj scale but, turn the turn speed up to quick, set the world size to small, with random terrain generation and a full house of 16 civs, and watch your hour-or-so long chaotic power struggle ensue.

Of course, if you were looking for a more epic game, the RevDCM mod pack alongside one of the larger scale earth maps, or a huge scale random map, will set you up for one of the most enjoyable empire building sim game experiences you can get.

To round up, a flexible game with stunning audio, that can be tailored and played to pretty much anyone's needs. A great game and worth picking up.

Best expansion for the best PC game out there. The base game, Civilization IV, is great. It is a really in depth "civilization simulator." You take control of a civilization starting at the dawn of time all the way to the modern era and beyond. The game is very in depth with all of the options at your disposal for how you manage your government, economy, religion, espionage, foreign policy, and many other factors. You can be Gandhi and set up a fascist theocracy with a socialist economy and nuke everyone on the planet. There is a lot of literature out there about how spectacular this game is so I‚Äôll just stop here.

One of the few flaws is the combat. It is all percentage based, so you can get in some pretty frustrating situations. Maybe you go into a battle where you have and 80+ percent chance of winning, but there is still a chance you can lose. Even at 97+percent I‚Äôve lost some times. This combat system is extremely frustrating when you ‚Äúget haxed‚Äù and lose on battle you should have won. Another issue is that in late game the combat really just becomes ‚Äúwho can have the most units crammed into a tile.‚Äù Your (and your opponents‚Äô) empire will get so big and have so much production that it becomes quite cumbersome to manage a war with all the military units you‚Äôll have around. Since you can fit literally infinite units in one space, it really becomes a contest of who can get the biggest army and march from city to city. These flaws pale in comparison to how great and addicting this game is, however.

This expansion, beyond the sword, is the best. It adds even more units, buildings, and civilizations to the game. Also, it comes pre-loaded with some of the best mods, including Rhye‚Äôs and Fall of Civilization, which takes this game to a whole new level. Over all it‚Äôs as close to a 10/10 game I have ever seen. You won‚Äôt regret spending the money to buy this, especially when it is on sale.

Best balanced version of all the Civ games in my opinion, and Beyond the Sword specifically adds a bit of interest to the later ages compared to Warlords and Vanilla via corporations, although to be honest few games are still meaningfully in play by that point. The improved epic game speed changes are quite beneficial if you like to play at slower speeds - essential if you want to play a more war oriented game on larger maps in my opinion, so that you actually spend time using the intermediate units rather than them being obselete by the time they reach the front lines.

The extra civs and leaders obviously always is a nice bonus, and they generally avoid being too similar to existing ones (within the limitations of how many there are with all the expansions enabled). The AI improvements I didn't notice too much myself from playing Warlords, but while the AI isn't great, it is competent enough in most spheres, particularly when given production bonuses at the higher difficulties, although the diplomacy aspect remains somewhat erratic, and invasions by sea tend to be a weakness.

A solid round based strategy game with some nice features Civ5 lacks but also some things that take a while to get used to. I recommend to get only Beyond the Sword, no need to buy the other versions as BTS includes them and is stand alone.

Features:
- Cultural Borders, I really miss this feature in newer Civs. It's so much fun to see your culture pumping cities capture the ai miniature settlements near your borders without ever going to war.
- Vasal States: threaten other nations into becoming your vasals. Vasals will give you one of their resources for free and always vote for you. A much better way than in Civ5 where the defeated, down to 1 city civs need to be wiped out to get rid of them sabotaging you at every oportunity.

Drawbacks:
- Stack of Doom: Infinite stacking units turn the war strategy into a simple zerg rush. The bigger doom stack wins.
- ranged combat, airforce and siege weapons: after having played civ5 a long time they handling of those units feels just wrong here

This game is just fantastic.

Not even counting the nearly 50 hours I've played this game on steam, I've probably got several hundred hours logged from the first time I bought the physical copy of this game. 

One of the things I like most about this incarnation of the Civ formula is the variety of ways you can play, and the customizeability of each game. You can set how many players/AI, there's a great variety of map types, and quite a few settings for how you want the game to behave as you play. In the game, you can micro-manage as much as you want (or s little as you want), with settings/tweaks to the production values of individual cities, or you can just set everything to auto. While I've always prefered a tech/diplomatic approach to winning the game, there's also a pretty good combat system as well for those that prefer launching stacks of archers and catapaults at their enemies.

This game isn't perfect. Some find it to be too micro-managey, despite the "auto" options. Others find certain systems to be lacking in complexity - the "stacks" combat often gets a lot of flack. If you're on the fence, read more reviews to see that the problems are, and decide if that will bother you. But also look at how many hundreds of hours people put into this game - even the folks complaining.

Civ IV: Beyond the Sword is the ultimate version of the now-classic Strategy title.

The game offers a turn-based look at history from the stone age to modern times, as is the case with all Civ games. What sets IV apart from the rest of the series is the sheer depth of the different mechanics that the player must manage to be successful. These include, but are not limited to: Economy, Military, Population, Health, Technology, and Espionage. With all of that work to do across the different eras of human history, it is easy to say that the turns you take in Civ IV will be longer than any other in the series.

How you deal with this fact is up to your personal preference. However, one thing is certain, Civ IV is extremely well streamlined, and even new players will be right at home with the mechanics with a modicum of perseverence. As someone who struggled with Civ III, I had fully grasped the mechanics of Civ IV by my tenth hour of gameplay: easy to learn, hard to master.

Ultimately, I recommend this game wholeheartedly to strategy fans. If you have Civ V, consider this the wise granddaddy of that great game. It is a wholly different and in some ways far more rewarding experience. If you have never played a Civ game before, Civ IV is a deeper choice, though if you are impatient and seek a more casual experience, the excellent Civ V is recommended.

Part of the legendary *Civilization series*, this turn-based strategy (TBS) games reward careful planning. Unlike its newer sibling, Civilizations 5, Civ IV allows you to fine tune every aspect of your civilization. For some, this means tedious micromanagement. But for people who like fine-grained control (a.k.a., 'control freaks', like me), this game is much better than (the much-simplified) Civ 5.

The "Beyond the Sword" (BtS) expansion is not only a bugfix of the previous Civilizations IV releases, but also introduces some 'twist' to the gameplay. In addition to the 'Great Generals' units of Civ IV Warlords, BtS expands on the importance of Espionage, and the introduction of the 'Corporations' allows players a 'second attempt' at 'religion', but with more devastating economic effects.

Simply put: If you're not a twitch gamer, but a strategic gamer who likes deep, encompassing games, then this game is for you.
Best Civ ever. Which means best game ever.

Sid Meier's Civilization has been the example of 4X games and Civ4 holds that legacy strong. Beyond the Sword is easily the best turn based strategy game I have ever had the pleasure of playing.

Now, there is a caveat. This game is complicated and the expansions only make it more complicated. The appeal here is to a player who has an intellectual bent, who likes a game experience that takes its time and requires considerable attention to detail. Turns can take upwards of 15 minutes on a larger map with dozens of simultaneous factors to keep in mind. To me, that sounds like an engaging challenge where there's always something going on, but if it sounds like a tedius grind then this is not the game for you.

As a fan of Sid's Civ games I love the expansions available under Civ IV's Beyond the Sword. Civilization IV is pretty great on its own but the various expansions make for many new avenues of gameplay. I think more is offered with Beyond the Sword than many of hte Civ V expansions.

The complexity of the game is daunting to some, but it is easy to learn - yet hard to master - like any skill-based game.

With random world generation and around 20 civilizations to play, along with a sliding scale for challenge level and multiplayer options, potential replayability is high for anyone looking to get deeply involved in complex strategy.

This is pretty much as good as traditional Civ gets, IMO. There are issues: not being able to found a Republic unless you build the Great Pyramid or reach the Renaissance is just silly; the generation of Commerce and turning it into Gold and Beakers is pretty obtuse for new players; and representing cultures like the Zulu and Aztecs with only warlike leaders is basically racist erasure. Uprisings are depicted as things that prevent a 'side' from 'winning' or something that is incited by another 'side', with no option to pursue victory as a revolutionary leader. But as a game presented as a simplifed account of human history, it's enormously fun if you like playing a conqueror, technocrat or schemer.

On higher difficulties the trades and demands are still weighted towards the AI but its NOT AS ridiculous and you're more inclined to take them.
You CHOOSE your friends. You CANNOT please Everyone.

What it does have is the classic Vanilla Civ IV gameplay, refined by all the expansion packs, which means it has a ton of content of all sorts (civs, leaders, wonders, buildings) and a few added game systems such as espionage. 

If you wanna experience the megalomaniac thrill of being the emperor of a budding civ, expanding, teching and trying to outmanoeuver some vile AIs, you're gonna like it. If you like to spread religions and build bonus multipliers in your cities as you watch your income grow, this game is especially for you. If you like to get some horses, rush cavalry and crush with numbers, you might want to pick the Mongols or Hannibal to have your fun.

Civilization IV is probably my most played game of all time.  I suspect less man hours were put into planning some land invasions.  Beyond the Sword is the expansion pack that made everything about Civilization IV better, plus is necessary for some of the really good mods outs there such as Fall from Heaven.

So, I am certainly going to recommend it.  It is a strategy game that got a lot right.  The gameplay mechanics encourage expansion, but simultaneously impose reasonable limts.  New technologies can alter the way the game is played, making a very different strategic picture through railroads, airplanes, and democracy.  The religion mechanic adds great flavor and some interesting gameplay.  Diplomacy is easy to understand, but hard to exploit.

There are some flaws.  Get to far behind and you've lost, even if it takes another 100 years for the axe to actually fall.  The end game becomes a bit to grindy with units becoming to common.  

Still, the hundreds of hours I've spent playing this game is a testament to both its addictiveness and its quality.
Having played the game and the whole series since the start, I find this to be the game of the centuries! No other game can be so addictive!

The last expansion for a great game.  Play this till your eyes bleed and then play some more!

The already amazing Civilization IV becomes so much better with BTS. Beyond the Sword adds ten new civilizations (examples: Korea, Byzantine, Holy Rome), 5 new leaders (examples: Lincoln, Stalin), some scenarios from modders of Civilization IV (including the fantastic Rhye's and Fall of Civilization, or RFC), and gameplay additions that make the game funner and more addicting than the original Civilization IV. RFC is amazing. In RFC, you can choose a civ, and play as them, in world history. You can also change history - for example, the Germans winning World War II, or the Mongolian Empire reaching from Africa to China. I have to criticize, though, that, if you want to play as, say, the Americans, I am pretty sure you have to select another Civ and play as them until 1775. But other than that, RFC is good! But not as good as BTS itself.

This was a game I played hundreds of hours on long before I discovered Steam. As soon as it was available, it was a must-have purchase for me.

Civ IV is a sublime strategy in the truest sense of the word. Spanning over 6000 years of human history, you'll start with a single settler forming a tribal village. Dozens of hours later you could be sending a fleet of warships to control oil deposits in the north pole, taking control of the global market with a corporation monopoly, or ordering a charge of knights in a futile last strike against an Aztec airbase.

It's a game that provides multiple ways to win and even several options to get to each of those conditions. You will compete against up to 18 other nations using diplomacy, warfare, exploration and luck to establish an empire. You will need to stake a claim on finite global resources, defend your borders, make friends and defeat enemies. Spread religion and corporations to control the masses and bankrupt your ememies. Deploy spies to see enemy troop movements or sabotage their reserach and production. Build great wonders to boost your cultural impact. Difficulty is easily scaleable and 'tweakable', providing a fantastic challenge. Perhaps you will triumph...and perhaps you will meet your end at the hands of Mahatma Ghandi's nuclear arsenal. One thing is for sure...you will have many, many replays of this game.

THEN there are the scenarios - various historical or fictional settings that tweak the rules and gives special conditions. See if you can spot the mod (inclided with the game) that inspired their later offering - 'X:COM Enemy Unknown'.

In Short: The greatest strategy game ever made*- there'll be no need for friends, jobs or even sunlight anymore with this baby. The only reason you should not be buying it is because you were reading this review. But it's over now...so go guy it!

*This includes the more recent title 'Civ V' -- a competent game, but inferior in my humble opinion.
This, for me, is where the Civilisation franchise reached it's pinnacle. Just about everything is perfectly balanced... and utilised to perfection.

If I could live forever, but was only allowed to play one game for the rest of time, I would pick this one. Endless replayability. So many gameplay options, modifications and settings. And its fun too!

Ruining lives since 2007. BtS followed Warlords and improved the vanilla Civ IV to an amazing level of polish.
The base game deserved instant accolades for interface improvements, excellent sound (Baba Yetu song, units languages, Leonard Nimoy's voice), and being a distillation of the series gameplay formula.
The expansions took this cornucopia of options and increased it further, while losing nothing of the successful gameplay. A particular mention to the mods and scenarios like Rhyes' mod and Fall from Heaven 2.

Beyond the Sword is easily one of my favourite expansions for Civ IV, making the game feel even more epic in scope.  The mods developed for it also change the game in amazing ways.  You'll lose yourself for hours, possibly days, playing this game.

The sun shines on the grassy plains. You and your tribe have wandered for many moons. But now the village elders have consulted with the shamans, and have advised you to cease. For you have found the perfect place to call your new home. The grass is green, and ripe for farming. The river sparkles and dances in the golden blaze of the setting sun, waiting to be tamed, to feel the keel of boats along her great girth. And beyond, the distant forested hills call to you. Maybe someday, you and your tribe will dig deep into the womb of the Earth-mother, and harvest the metals that lie within. 


You gaze with delight as the procession passes your balcony. The Emperor Jeffersonius himself, in his resplendent robes! His chariot rattles down the cobblestones as the victorious troops of the Ethiopian campaign march trimuphantly behind him, shields and swords gleaming in the summer sunshine. "They have tamed Ethiopia, you know..." you hear your father remark. " We must move to the colonies soon, else there'll be no space left for us!" Your mother laughs gently, and pats you on the head. " We must think of Marcus. His education must take precedence, and you know old Ezrum refuses to travel....." You smile, and throw flowers into the path of those brave legionaires, who fight for the Empire so you may have the best of all  things, here in the capital of the world, Washington.

Your horse gallops wildly through the smoggy streets. Gentlemen of industry, the representatives of the counties, aristocratic ladies, all of them jump and stumble out of the way as you ride past, angrily cursing your receding backside. Along the way, the butt of your rifle thuds against a slow-moving old academic, leaving him senseless upon the cobblestones. You care not, though. You have urgent news for the High Chancellor, and must not be impeded. A rebellion in the Indian colonies! The impertinence astounds you. How dare they, those brown-faced mongrels, rebel against the American Republic? You gallop up the steps of the Palace, and stop to gaze at the Eiffel Tower, under construction on the south banks of the Appatomac River. The fools....the nation that builds such wonders will not fall prey to such nefarious misdeeds! Reflection done, you proceed into the chambers of the High Chancellor to give him the news.

You sigh as you read the fine print of the tender submitted by the cold IronCorp executives. Summary privatization, first right to exploration contracts, government subisidzation of the first twelve months of drilling in the Thames estuary, etecetera, etcetera....your eyes water and you fling the document away, feeling the need for a break. You wipe your glasses and stroll over to the window. You gaze wistfully across the expanse of glass, neon and concrete that obscures your view of the Cristo Redentor, perched high above the city on Zara Yacob Hill. You ponder for a moment....is modernity really worth all this? Did all your ancestors, all the thousands of years of history, all the breakthroughs in science and technology and reason, all the accumulated pride, joy, triumph and defeat of the last four thousand years, lead to this? In the year of our Lord, 1955, you're standing here, in the Pentagon, trying to decide between two equally heartless, vile corporations. Is this what society has become?Ah, well. You wipe your glasses for the last time and shuffle back to your desk, reaching for the legal papers with a weary sigh. You look up at the television to see the newsman babbling about a terrorist attack on the Taj Mahal in Kyoto. Surprise, surprise......

"Oogaboog, wake up!"

"hhmmphr....grumble...what?"

"Chief Washington has called a meeting. He want all us warriors to attend. Quickly, get your club."

"....sigh...okay. But remind me to tell you about strange dream I had just now. Big strange."

"Okay, now come , we'll be late!"

You exit, yawning, into the golden rays of the setting sun, hoping that Washington would let you settle here. After all, the shamans did say it was a good place, and you are tired from all the wandering.

Civilization is a particularly ancient series (excuse the unintentional irony) with a lot of prestige in its name brand and its benefactor, Mr. Meier. For the most part, each fan has their favourite game in the series past CivII, But Civilization IV in any case is my favourite one. With a wealth of content and a phenominal fanbase and modding scene, it stands as one of the most complete and interesting single-player games in existence, bar the somewhat clunky engine it runs on and the weak UI. Buy, play, mod, enjoy.

Civilzation 4 contiunes to raise the bar from the previous civilization games. The game is streamlined in a good way, while keeping the depth of strategy of the previous titles. Religion adds a new dimension to the game in huge ways. Every country is unique and has advantages and disadvanteges, you can find one to suite your playstyle or difficulty curve. The graphics, the soundtrack and the technology quotes (done by lenoard nemoy) are all excellent. 

If I had one complaint, it would be the difficulty. I have played CiV2, Civ3 and alpha centrai. I can say with certinty that the AI is much harder in this game. In previous games I could win on the hardest settings. In this game I lose on the easy settings. This can get frustrating as you can easilly sink at least three hours into one game and lose. The music can also get repetive as there are not many songs in the soundtrack.

This game is worth every penny, if you liked other Civ games get it!

It's like crack.  You start getting into it, then when it's time to stop, you say to yourself, "Just one more turn".  When your friends come knocking on your door at 3am a week later, asking why you haven't been to work the last week, you tell them "It's ok, I can quit whenever I want."   They try to have an intervention, but you don't show up because you just discovered Uranium.

Then the electric company shuts off your power cuz you haven't paid your bil in three months.  So you move in with a friend for a week.  Two months later, he's kicking you out, but it's okay because you traded your desktop for his laptop and you can play at an internet caf√©.

Then finally, you discover space travel and take your civilization to a new galaxy and you start playing the space colony mod.  Your achievement' so great you wind up in a local newspaper - because you're the first kid in your town to die in an internet caf√© while playing a video game.  You're not even Korean.

Unlike Warlord which really adds a few new civs and a leader head or two as well as some admittedly good scenarios Beyond The Sword is the true expansion for Civ IV.

BTS gives you some much needed features including a revamped espionage system, corporations which give you resource bonuses and boots and a random event system that will make sure that you won't lose the lead against the other civs in the game.

I cannot reccomend Civ5 for the laughable commercialization and watered down nature of it. I cannot reccomend 3 as it has some rather aggrivating flaws. Civ4 is the middle bed, the middle porridge, and the middle chair of the grand dining table of Civilization. It is just right.

At the beginning of the game, keep at least one warrior on your city, while you research Bronze Working. Once you've got that, build an archer, and fortify him on your city. Use your previously fortifying warrior to look for bronze. Once you find it, build a settler and make a city on/near the bronze. There, enjoy your swordsmen. That should make things easier for you.

Definitely best Civ game since Civ 2.  Arguably better due to the immense number of quality mods you can get for it.  Like high fantasy? Check out Fall from Heaven.  Want to revisit Alpha Centauri? Try Planetfall.  Many, many, MANY hours lovingly spent on this game.
